story_clean: A murder charge was filed Tuesday against a La Puente woman accused of running over her boyfriend with her car outside a motel after an argument last weekend. Sharon Kay Hood, 52, is scheduled to be arraigned June 8 at the Pomona courthouse in connection with the death of Randolph Morales, 51, according to the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office. Authorities said the two -- who had been dating for six years -- started arguing Sunday inside a motel room in the 500 block of North Azusa Avenue in La Puente. Hood abruptly left the room, and when Morales followed her outside, she ran him over with her car, prosecutors allege. He died at the scene. Hood was arrested the same day and has remained behind bars since then. If convicted of the murder charge, which includes the allegation of use of a deadly and dangerous weapon -- an automobile -- during the commission of the crime, Hood could face up to 26 years to life in state prison. -- City News Service, photo via Shutterstock

Fire investigators have determined a three-alarm fire in New Carrollton last month was "incendiary" and police have arrested the woman they believe set it because she was angry with an ex-boyfriend. Firefighters responded to a  fire at 5334 85th Avenue  just before 3:30 p.m. on Sept. 17 and found a working fire in a three-story garden-style apartment building, according to a report from Prince George's County Fire/EMS. After two hours, firefighters finally put out the blaze, but not before it damaged four apartment buildings, caused an estimated $2.2 million in damages, and displaced about 130 residents, the report states. Fortunately, no one was injured. Investigators identified a suspect and police arrested 32-year-old Natasha Ciara Joyner of New Carrolton on Thursday. She is charged "with several crimes after setting the fire because she was allegedly upset with an ex-boyfriend," the report states. Police charged her with first degree arson, second degree arson, first degree malicious burning, malicious destruction of property greater than $1,000, and reckless endangerment. More charges may be coming, authorities say. Image via Prince George's County Fire/EMS

A New York Police Department officer who lives in East Meadow was arrested on Thursday after authorities say he stole thousands of dollars from his landlord by filing forged military orders to qualify for reduced rent. According to District Attorney Madeline Singas, Eric Smith, 37, stole more than $34,000 from his landlord with the falsified documents. He surrendered on Thursday morning to DA detectives. "The defendant, a sworn member of the NYPD, is accused of drafting fake military orders and using those orders to dupe his landlord into giving him reduced rent," Singas said. "This benefit exists to help armed services members while they are deployed in defense of our county, but this defendant allegedly filed multiple fake orders and stole more than $34,000 in the process." According to Singas, Smith, an NYPD officer in the 41st Precinct, is a former member of the New York Army Air National Guard. From 2011 to 2014, he was on full time assignment to the Joint Task Force Empire Shield and was eligible to receive a reduced rent due to his deployment. Beginning in 2015 and through 2017, Smith allegedly filed forged military orders with his landlord to continue qualifying for reduced rent at the Mitchel Homes in East Meadow. Based on the investigation, Singas said Smith stole approximately $34,014.00 from his landlord, Balfour Beatty LLC, which operates the Mitchel Homes. Smith was arraigned on Thursday and charged with third-degree grand larceny, three counts of second-degree criminal possession of a forged instrument and three counts of first-degree falsifying business records. He was released on his own recognizance and is due back in court on May 21. He faces a maximum of seven years in prison. Photo: Nassau County District Attorney's Office

Manhattan Beach police circulated the name and photo of a suspect wanted for allegedly trying to burglarize a home under construction Thursday. Alisha Tapia, 29, is being sought as a suspect in the crime, which occurred about 2 p.m. Sunday in the 100 block of 32nd Place, said Manhattan Beach police Sgt. Tim Zins. "The reporting party stated a female suspect attempted to burglarize a home under construction," Zins said. "The female was described as wearing a white painter's suit and ventilator mask to disguise her identity." The homeowner chased the suspect and took a picture of her, Zins said. Detectives identified Tapia as the woman pictured by the homeowner, and obtained a warrant for her arrest on suspicion of attempted burglary, vandalism, and possession of burglary tools, Zins said. Tapia, whose last known address was in Long Beach, is described as Hispanic, 5 feet 4 inches tall, weighing 155 pounds, with brown hair and eyes. Anyone knowing her whereabouts was urged to call police at (310) 802-5140 or (310) 802-5123. City News Service and Patch staffer Emily Holland contributed to this post; Image via Manhattan Beach Police Department

A Woodstock man has been arrested under the accusation of sexually assaulting a pre-teen girl and is facing multiple felony charges, according to reports. The Northwest Herald reported a Woodstock press release as saying that Daniel Pollet, 35, of the 1400 block of Commons Drive, was charged Wednesday with predatory criminal sexual assault of a child and aggravated criminal sexual abuse. Woodstock police initially found about about the allegation from Centegra Hospital - Huntley officials. Police investigated and met with the victim to interview her. She told police that Pollet, who she knew, but is not a family member, had  sexually assaulted her  on multiple occasions, the Herald reported Woodstock Police Chief John Lieb as saying. Pollet now faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted of the most serious charge. He's being extradited from Wisconsin, where he was being held at the Walworth County Courthouse for a separate incident, a non-criminal matter. See more at the Northwest Herald Article image via Shutterstock

Washington County deputies on Sunday arrested a suspect who allegedly pointed a gun at three people walking through Vista Brook Park in Raleigh Hills. The suspect, Kadin E. Moore, told deputies it was a prank, and the gun, investigators learned, was just a realistic-looking toy Airsoft pistol. Moore, 19, of Beaverton, was taken to Washington County Jail and charged with menacing. Moore has since been released.  Deputies were dispatched just after 11 p.m. Aug. 26 to Vista Brook Park, 6697 S.W. 88th Ave. after a group of people asked a homeowner in the neighborhood to call 911.  The group of three later told deputies they were walking through the park when a person approached and pointed a gun at them. It's unclear if any words were said, but the trio reportedly ran out of the park toward a random home, where they asked the resident to call police.  After the trio described the suspect and the gun, deputies searched the park and along Fanno Creek Trail — where  on July 19 a 28-year-old woman was assaulted and raped .  After a brief search, deputies reportedly found Moore and identified her as the suspect based on witness descriptions. Moore, who identifies as a woman, told investigators she was just playing a prank on the three victims. None of the victims knew Moore prior to incident, sheriff's officials said.  After Moore's arrest, deputies learned the gun was an Airsoft toy. Moore does not have any apparent criminal history in Oregon. Sheriff's officials confirmed there is no reason to believe this incident is at all connected to  the sexual assault that occurred in July . Anyone with information about either incident, however, is encouraged to call Washington County Sheriff's deputies at 503-629-0111. Image via Washington County Sheriff's Office

Police say a Scott Township man sexually assaulted his daughter's 9-year-old friend during several sleepovers in 2008. Roland V. McFarland, 61, is charged with two counts each of indecent assault and unlawful contact with a minor, along with one count each of child endangerment, corruption of minors and false imprisonment. According to a criminal complaint supporting his arrest, McFarland carried the girl to his bed on "several occasions" when she stayed over for sleepovers with her friend at their home in Glendale. The girl told police McFarland touched her inappropriately and made her touch his genitals. Other times, she was able to fight him off, police said. said the girl, who is now 14, came forward last month after talking to her parents about what happened. Scott police Sgt. Jeff Skees said she didn't discuss it before because she was "embarrassed and ashamed" about what happened. However, the girl's parents said they had suspicions and confronted McFarland in 2008. He denied the accusations, police said, and the parents decided the best way to handle the situation was to keep their daughter away from McFarland and his home in Glendale. WPXI-TV is also reporting that  police filed additional charges against Roland , accusing him of sexually assaulting a second girl. Police charged him with additional counts of corruption of minors, indecent assault, child endangerment and unlawful contact with minors. McFarland is being held at Allegheny County Jail after he was unable to post bond. Like the  Chartiers Valley Patch Facebook page  or sign up for our  Daily E-mail Newsletter

A man who worked as an animal control officer in New Jersey has been charged with sexually assaulting a child in Bucks County, officials said. Saul Nathan Barson, 29, who worked as Princeton's animal control officer, has been suspended without pay for the alleged assault, which police say happened on Feb. 3 at Pat Livezey Park in Solebury Township. Barson, of Lambertville, was arrested on Monday, and charged with involuntary deviate sexual intercourse, statutory sexual assault, sexual assault, indecent assault, corruption of minors and criminal use of a communication facility. Barson is accused of sexually assaulting a 13-year-old at the park, located off Route 202.  Bail was set at $300,000, 10 percent option, Solebury Township Police said. He was remanded to Bucks County Prison. Anyone who may have had contact with Barson in regards to the charges are asked to contact Solebury Township Police at 215-348-7400. Barson was connected to the crime after the child and his parents reported the assault by an adult known to the boy as "Jake," according to the  Princeton Packet . The mother provided a license plate number to the pickup truck the assailant was alleged to have been driving, leading police to identify Barson as the alleged culprit. By Anthony Bellano and Kara Seymour The attached image of Nate Barson was provided

A 25-year-old man has been arrested in connection with a series of robberies that targeted banks in three South Bay cities between July and last week, San Jose police said today.  Spencer Havens was arrested without incident on Sept. 15 at his San Jose home, police said. He is suspected of committing six bank robberies in San Jose, Cupertino and Sunnyvale between July 19 and Sept. 13, police said. In each incident, Havens allegedly approached a bank teller with a demand note and said he had a gun that was never seen, police said. He is connected with at least two bank robberies in San Jose at a Chase bank at 405 Blossom Hill Road around 3:15 p.m. on Aug. 19 and a Wells Fargo bank at 7270 Bollinger Road shortly before 2 p.m. on Aug. 25, police said. No injuries were reported in either case, according to police. Havens is also a suspect in a July 22 robbery at a Chase Bank at 1234 West El Camino Real in Sunnyvale, Department of Public Safety Capt. Shawn Ahern said. He was booked into the Elmwood Correctional Facility in Milpitas on $300,000 bail, according to online jail records. Anyone with information on the robberies is asked to call San Jose police detectives Drago or Juan Hernandez at (408) 277-4166. Those who wish to remain anonymous can call Silicon Valley Crime Stoppers at (408) 947-7867. --Bay City News/Images via SJPD

Denver police are seeking a man accused of robbing multiple fast-food restaurants.  Police and Crime Stoppers released a video surveillance photos of a man they say robbed McDonalds restaurants in the area on May 19 and May 21.  Police described the suspect as a white male, around 6'1" tall who was wearing sunglasses and a backpack.  A $2,000 reward is offered for information leading to the arrest of the person in the video photos, police said. Tipsters may call Metro Denver Crime Stoppers at 720-913-7867. The tip-line is open 24hours a day, 7 days a week. To collect reward and remain anonymous, callers must call the tip line.

A Peninsula masseur is accused of inappropriately touching a woman at a local "foot spa" this week, and has been arrested on suspicion of sexual battery, police say.  Shidong Li, 51 of Monterey, allegedly assaulted the 40-year-old woman around 2:15 p.m. Tuesday while massaging her at the Four Seasons Foot Spa at 106 Park Place in Millbrae, according to Det. Sal Zuno of the San Mateo County Sheriff's Office. "After leaving the business the victim called 911 to report the incident," Zuno said in a press release. "During the investigation the victim positively identified 51 year old Shidong Li as the suspect in the Sexual Battery." Li was ultimately arrested and booked into the Maguire Correctional Facility, Zuno said. Now, sheriff's officials are looking for any additional possible victims related to the case. "The Sheriff's Office is sharing this information in hopes to help other potential victims come forward," Zuno said. Anyone with information about Li or the Four Seasons Foot Spa has been asked to call San Mateo County sheriff's Detective Joe Cang at (650) 259-2417 or the anonymous tip line at (800) 547-2700. at 1-800-547-2700. — Image via San Mateo County Sheriff's Office

One of the men accused of killing a Mount Pleasant couple in St. Maarten has reportedly confessed to the crime, according to media on the Dutch Caribbean island. Meyshane Kemar Johnson, 28, reportedly confessed to police that he was involved in the Sept. 19 slaying of Michael and Thelma King,  according the St. Martin News Network.  The couple was found dead on Sept. 21 from apparent stab wounds. Police arrested Johnson on Sept. 23 and then charged a second suspect, a 17-year-old, earlier this week.

A woman was arrested just north of Rosemont last week for allegedly throwing six steak knives at her longtime boyfriend, according to a Sacramento County Sheriff's Department crime log released earlier this week. Rosalyn Vantassell, a 49-year-old resident of Tuolumne Drive in the La Riviera area, assaulted her boyfriend of 14 years on June 1, according to the crime log. One of the knives she threw hit the man in the scalp, the department said. The man had to be taken to the hospital, and when Vantassell visited him the next day, she was arrested by hospital police, the crime log stated. The victim had a restraining order against Vantassell and she is currently on probation, but the two had been living together, according to the crime log. Vantassell is currently being held at the Sacramento County Main Jail on felony charges of assault with a deadly weapon and domestic violence, as well as a misdemeanor charge of violating a court order. Her bail is set at $105,000, and she is next due in court on Monday.  was caused by an argument between a 27-year-old man and his wife, according to the crime log. The suspect and his wife allegedly argued before a second man tried to intervene and defend the wife, the department said. The suspect shot the intervening man, and chased after him firing several more gunshots, according to the crime log. The suspect is described only as a 27-year-old black male with black hair and brown eyes, standing 5-foot-5 and weighing 140 pounds. A more recent crime log was released Thursday, but no nearby incidents were listed.

Andrea Sneiderman is set to be arraigned for a third time Tuesday, now that a judge has thrown out four non-murder charges against her. Sneiderman is accused of arranging for the death of her husband, Rusty Sneiderman, who was gunned down outside their children's Dunwoody daycare in 2010. Sneiderman's former boss, Hemy Neuman, was charged with Rusty Sneiderman's death. He was found guilty but mentally ill by a jury in 2012. Sneiderman is still facing malice murder and felony murder charges in connection with the death of her late husband, along with charges for allegedly giving false statements to law enforcement officials. However, DeKalb County Superior Judge Gregory Adams ruled on May 1 that four counts of in the indictment "did not meet the standard" for criminal indictments. She was first arraigned on an eight-count indictment and then a second time when additional charges were added. Now, she is being arraigned after charges have been dismissed and clarified. In former arraignments, Sneiderman has pleaded not guilty to charges against her. She has also repeatedly denied any involvement in her husband's death or any romantic involvement with her former boss, Neuman. She is currently living under house arrest at her parents' home after she was released on bond a few weeks after her arrest. Her trial is set for July 29.

The Marin County District Attorney's Office filed murder charges Tuesday against two Novato High School students and an accessory to  murder charge against a third student .   Juan Carlos Martinez Henriquez, 17, and Edwin Guevara, 16, are charged with the  premeditated shooting murder  while lying in wait of Edwin Josue Ramirez Guerra, 17, of San Rafael on Wednesday.   The complaint identifies Martinez Henriquez as the shooter, but alleges Guevara also was armed with a firearm.  Both teens also are charged with the attempted murder of a second student, who was shot and stabbed but survived, on May 25.   Martinez Henriquez also is charged with aggravated mayhem for allegedly intentionally disfiguring part of Ramirez Guerra's body.   A third defendant, Elmer Fernando Machado-Rivera, 21, of San Rafael, is charged with being an accessory to the murder and attempted murder by harboring and concealing Martinez Henriquez to avoid arrest and prosecution.   The teen victims, also Novato High School students, were found around 5:30 p.m. at the end of Fairway Drive miles from Novato High School.   The student who survived called 911 and identified the three suspects, and Ramirez Guerra was found dead at the scene. Marin County sheriff's officials have not said what the crime was about.   The defendants, who are being prosecuted as adults, are scheduled for arraignment Wednesday morning in Marin County Superior Court, Assistant Marin County District Attorney Barry Borden said. Previous:   --Bay City News

Six defendants have been indicted in connection to an armed robbery reported in September just outside downtown Canton. A Cherokee County grand jury on Tuesday, Jan. 9 indicted Nicole Ann Clary of Jasper, William Elijah Harris of Acworth, Shamer Lamar Jones of Canton, Marissa Elizabeth Lemieux of Jasper, Brittany Elizabeth McGuire of Jasper and Deshaun Gabriel Tiller of Canton each on two counts of aggravated assault and one count each of armed robbery and possession of cocaine with the intent to distribute. They are accused of robbing a man of money and drugs at a home on Sept. 21 on Jefferson Circle. According to the indictment, the defendants held up the victim using a BB gun and stole $230 from him during the robbery.  Officers with the Canton Police Department were dispatched to the call of a  robbery  and met with the victim, who was able to provide police with a description of the suspected vehicle. Police tracked down the red Dodge Dart on East Main Street near Interstate 575, conducted a traffic stop and took the suspects into custody.  Meanwhile, officers and detectives arrived at the residence and began working the crime scene as part of the investigation. Additional statements were taken and a search warrant was secured for the residence. Detectives were able to recover drugs and the firearm allegedly used during the robbery.  "Detectives determined that the complainant in the case was set up by the suspects to meet him at the vacant residence in order to forcibly rob him of the cash and narcotics he was bringing to the meet(ing) location," the Canton Police Department previously said.  Image via Shutterstock

Authorities arrested two men following a pursuit from San Lorenzo that ended with a car crash in Walnut Creek on Wednesday night, an Alameda County sheriff's spokesman said today.  Shortly before 10 p.m., deputies in the area of Hesperian Boulevard and Grant Avenue attempted to make a traffic stop on a vehicle, sheriff's Sgt. J.D. Nelson said. Nelson said the vehicle's driver failed to yield to the deputies and led them on a chase through Castro Valley and into Dublin and then onto Interstate Highway 680.   At that point, Nelson said the deputies stopped pursuing the car and California Highway Patrol officers picked up the chase, passing through San Ramon and Danville. The officers followed the car into Walnut Creek, where it crashed. The two men inside the car were then arrested on suspicion of evading law enforcement officers and for outstanding warrants, Nelson said.   The CHP officers also found items in the car reported stolen from prior burglaries, and Nelson said detectives are still trying to determine the suspects' involvement in those alleged crimes.   Nelson said he didn't have information on where or when the burglaries occurred.   As of this afternoon, Nelson said the names of the two men arrested are not being released because detectives were still investigating their possible involvement in other crimes. --Bay City News

The Lower Southampton Police have identified a fifth subject they believe is involved in an alleged counterfeit check cashing scheme. According to  Phillyburbs , Lower Southampton Police issued a warrant Wednesday for Terrance Darrell Walker, 22, of Philadelphia, who is suspected of using fake identification to illegally cash $2,200 worth of checks against a local health care staffing company's account. Walker is suspected of conspiring with Jon Whitters, 26, of Philadelphia and Thomas Manigault, 35, of Upper Darby to used fake IDs to cash seven counterfeit checks for more than $5,000 on Sept. 19, police said. They used business information and bank numbers for Vitacare, located on E. Street Road, police said. Walker is charged with 12 felonies, including identity theft, forgery and access device crimes, according to police. Read more: Police Investigate Counterfeit Check Scheme The five subjects, police said, stole more than $10,000 combined from two Feasterville medical staffing businesses last month,  Phillyburbs  reported. Demetrius Green, 20, of Philadelphia, is scheduled to be arraigned this week on 13 felony charges, including identity theft, forgery and access device crimes. He is incarcerated in Philadelphia, according to police. Whitters is facing six felony charges, including forgery and access device crimes, and related misdemeanors, surrendered last week. He is in Bucks County prison in lieu of 10 percent of $25,000 bail. McFarlane is accused of using a phony driver's license to cash two checks totaling $1,471 on Encore's account, police said. Lower Southampton detective Eric Landamia told Patch that was expected to turn himself in at 10 a.m. Tuesday.

Edgewood police arrested two men Dec. 20 during a burglary in progress at a home in the 800 block of East Hutchinson Avenue. One of the suspects, Dejon Edwards Jackson, 20, of Pittsburgh was apprehended after he jumped from a second-story window in the home. Edgewood police charged him with criminal trespass, burglary and conspiracy-burglary in connection with the incident. He was held in Allegheny County Jail, unable to post a $10,000 bond, until Dec. 27, when he was released on his own recognizance. A second suspect, Michael Patterson, 18, of Wilkinsburg hid on the third floor of the house until he was discovered by police and taken into custody. He is charged with criminal trespass, burglary and receiving stolen property. He was held in Allegheny County Jail, unable to post a $5,000 cash bond, until Dec. 27, when he was released on his own recognizance. Both men face a preliminary hearing before District Judge Kim M. A Beaumont man was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of lewd and lascivious acts with a minor under 14 years of age, police announced. Sixty-year-old Miguel Lazo is accused of sexually assaulting one of his own young family members.  According to police, the arrest stems from a months-long investigation into the allegations that first arose when officers were called to a local hospital emergency room in early 2018 "to investigate a report that a female juvenile had been sexually assaulted by a family member," according to a police statement.  "It was determined that the alleged assault occurred in a family member's residence in the City of Beaumont," police said.  A warrant was issued for Lazo, who is a teacher in the El Monte Union High School District, after the case was submitted to and reviewed by the Riverside County District Attorney's office, police said. El Monte and Beaumont police worked together to arrest Lazo in the 3000 block of Tyler Avenue, which maps data indicates is El Monte High School, on Tuesday. "His arrest and this investigation does not involve any allegations related to his employment with the El Monte Union High School District," Beaumont police said. Additional details regarding the alleged assault were not provided.  Police asked that if anyone has information related to the case, to call 951-769-8500. Information may also be reported anonymously via email at crimetips@beaumontpd.org.

A Mahopac man faces a misdemeanor charge after being accused of stealing from a pharmacy. Yorktown Police arrested Lado Tabidze, 32, of Mahopac, and charged him with petit larceny. Police said around 4:30 p.m. July 29 an officer was sent to Taconic Pharmacy on Lee Road in Yorktown for a report of a previous theft and the suspect returning to the store.   An investigation revealed Tabidze allegedly stole a bottle of Children's Tylenol around 7:14 p.m. July 26. The item was worth $7.39. He was arrested and taken to police headquarters for processing. Tabidze was released on $200 bail and is due back in Yorktown Justice Court Sept. 5. Image via Shutterstock.

An alleged puppy thief is in the Gwinnett County jail, accused of robbing an Alabama woman of two French bulldog puppies she advertised for sale on the internet. Gwinnett Police said Ronald Junior Camenish, 18, of Lawrenceville, faces robbery charges in the case. He reportedly snatched the puppies away from the woman after they met at a grocery store on Duluth Highway Thursday afternoon to complete the transaction. Camenish was arrested later and the puppies were found safe. Gwinnett officers responded to 996 Duluth Highway in unincorporated Lawrenceville around 1:30 p.m. after the woman called police. The woman told officers she spoke to the suspect over the phone and agreed to meet him in Georgia to sell the puppies. "The suspect told the victim that he would pay her extra to drive the puppies to Lawrenceville," Gwinnett Police Public Information Officer Cpl. Michele Pihera said in the Friday morning email. "After the two met, the suspect pushed the victim and grabbed one of the puppies from the victim's hands. He then grabbed the other puppy from a carrier and fled on foot." The lead investigator identified Camenish as the suspect. He was arrested at his residence. The puppies were found in the basement unharmed, and were returned to the woman. Photos: Gwinnett Police PIO; Ronald Junior Camenish mugshot, Gwinnett County Jail

Area media are reporting that another Iowa State University football player is in trouble and alcohol might be to blame. That concludes a week of strange crime news that started over the weekend with a bar fight in which the owner was struck with a heel. In the latest incident, KCCI reports that Ames police used  pepper spray  on football player Jake Lattimer after breaking up a fight. Lattimer, 23, of Friley Road, was charged with disorderly conduct, public intoxication, first offense; and interference with official acts, according to Ames Police Department's daily arrest log. Lattimer has already been released from jail. Earlier in the week, one man received several charges after allegedly being involved in a at Club Element. He was accused of assaulting two bartenders and hitting the owner Scott Davis with a high heeled shoe. That same day a relieved herself in the back of a squad car. Another ISU football found passed out got zinged by a Taser after allegedly waking up and taking a fighting stance. SEE MORE ON PATCH

A man accused of  shooting two people dead in a red Dodge Durango  has been arrested almost two years after the murder, according to police. Kenrick Bayliss, 36, was charged Tuesday with murdering Christina Stubbs, 23, and Devon Hannibal, 27, in a car parked on Cleveland Street near Linden Boulevard on Friday, June 23, 2017, police said.  Hannibal, of Brooklyn, was shot several times and Stubbs, of Pompano Beach, Fla., was killed by a single bullet, police said. Police  released video footage of two suspects  days after the shooting and  arrested Gary Martin , 33, on July 5, said police.  Martin is currently being tried on murder and criminal possession of a weapon charges in Brooklyn Criminal Court, city records show.  Information about Bayliss' arraignment was not immediately available.  Photo by Renee Schiavone

Allegations of abuse at a state-funded facility for at-risk girls has led to the arrest of two, and an arrest warrant issued for another. The Care Cottage, a state-funded facility that specialized in the care of at-risk girls aged 6-17, allegedly received numerous reports from residents at the facility. Those complaints became public in May, and led to the dismissal of at least five employees from the facility. On Tuesday, investigators arrested Hiram Thigpen and Jasmin Lyons on abuse charges. Thigpen, who is charged with felony injury to a child, is accused of grabbing and throwing a child to the floor, then putting his knee on the child's neck, during an incident at the facility on April 11. He is still employed by the facility. Lyons, who is no longer employed at Care Cottage, is charged with felony injury to a disabled child for allegedly fractured a child's arm in October 2017, when she grabbed and twisted a child's arm, according to a press release fro the Montgomery County DA's Office. RELATED:  Montgomery County Girls Care Facility Raided However, Jadaniran Thompson, who is charged with felony injury to a child, is at large. Thompson, who is still employed at the facility, is accused of grabbing a child by the neck and choking her during a February incident, and scratching the child's neck. Anyone with any information on Thompson's whereabouts is asked to call the Montgomery County Crime Stoppers at 1800-392-7867. Image: Montgomery County DA Send your news tips to bryan.kirk@patch.com

Three men were arrested Wednesday night for allegedly robbing the TD Bank on Wade Hampton Boulevard earlier that day.  Johnathan Bragg, public information officer for the Greenville Police Department, said Joshua Earle Watson, 22, James Rodriguez McGowan, 28 and Jack Jenkins Jr, 27, were all arrested. The three reside at 108 Hudson Road in Greenville.  At roughly 11 a.m. Wednesday, two men armed with handguns entered the TD Bank on Wade Hampton Boulevard near Bob Jones University, hopped the counter and demanded money, leaving in a getaway car that was later found abandoned. There was a getaway driver waiting for the men to whisk them away in what police called a "very quick, likely organized" hit.  The trio are all charged with bank robbery, first degree assault and battery, kidnapping and possession of a weapon during a violent crime. A judge has not set any bond for any of the suspects.

Officers arrested a man on suspicion of possession of narcotics for sale and carrying a loaded and concealed firearm in Berkeley Wednesday, police said.  An officer patrolling the area around Willard Park at 5:39 p.m. recognized a man sitting in an SUV with the windows down on Regent Street near Derby Street, according to police. The officer, who knew the man was on probation, conducted a search and discovered several thousand dollars in his pants, police said. Continuing the search with the assistance of other officers, the officer allegedly found a loaded .45-caliber handgun in the SUV, powdered cocaine and other paraphernalia related to drug sales, according to police. The officer arrested the suspect, Terry Beasley, 38, of Alameda, on suspicion of possession of narcotics for sale, carrying a loaded and concealed firearm, possession of controlled substances while armed with a  loaded firearm, violating probation and other gun-related crimes. — Bay City News; Image via BPD

Devon Evans stands accused of burglarizing a Sarasota home last month while the people inside slept. So it might seem fitting that Sarasota Police officers say Evans was brought into custody after a tipster told detectives they could find him sleeping in a van. The case that led to 27-year-old's arrest unfolded in the early morning hours of April 24. At the time, police said someone forced their way into a home in the 1000 block of Cocoanut Avenue. The burglar, police noted in an email to media, removed several items of value before leaving. The home's occupants slept through the burglary and were uninjured. Get the  Sarasota Patch newsletter and alerts in your inbox . Shortly after the burglary, police announced Evans as a suspect. He remained elusive until May 12 around 4:25 a.m. when a tip came in that he could be found sound asleep in a van parked in the area of 29th Street and Dixie Avenue, the police department reported. That tip paid off, authorities say. Evans was charged with one felony count of burglary of an occupied dwelling. He was booked into the Sarasota County Jail following his arrest and was being held without bond as of Monday. Police have not said how Evans was linked to the crime. Further information is not being released at this time. Keep up with what's happening by  following Sarasota Patch on Facebook. Booking photo courtesy of the Sarasota Police Department

A Silver Spring man was arrested on a slew of charges including armed robbery, assault and more for a stabbing that occurred in Takoma Park, police said.  Vernon Robb Wynter, 37, is accused of an assault/robbery in the 900 block of East West Highway July 19. Officers responded to the area at around 5:50 p.m. and located the victim who had been robbed and stabbed in his arm, police said.  Video footage of the events that unfolded prior to the incident were obtained by Takoma Park Police, and detectives established Wynter as the suspect. The weapon used was also retrieved by police in the 6900 block of New Hampshire Ave., police said.  A warrant was issued for the arrest of Wynter. Wynter responded to the police station on Sept. 12 due to the outstanding warrant, police said. He was transported to the Montgomery County Central Processing Unit without incident. Wynter was charged with armed robbery, first- and second-degree assault and possession of a concealed dangerous weapon. Two men are now charged in connection to the homicide of a man whose body was left on a Dale City street Tuesday.  Prince William County Police arrested Juan Carlos Flores, 25, of no fixed address, on Wednesday in connection to the death of Barbaro Lupe Alonso-Irahola, 47, of no fixed address. The victim sustained trauma to his face from a blunt object and a knife, police said.  Police are still looking for another unidentified person who allegedly helped Flores dump Alonso-Irahola's body in a Dale City neighborhood.  They also charged Jose Miguel Diaz, 28, of Westminster Lane in Dale City, who owned the van used to dump Alonso-Irahola's body, Officer Jonathan Perok, a spokesman for the department, said in a press release. However, Flores reported used the van without Diaz's consent.  "The investigation revealed that the accused, Flores, was involved in the murder of the victim. The second suspect, Diaz, aided Flores after the murder took place but is not the second suspect seen on Cardin Pl by witnesses," Perok said in the release.  Flores is charged with first-degree murder and unauthorized use of a vehicle. Diaz is charged with accessory after the fact to murder. Court dates for both are set for Feb. 20.  Police have classified the case as a murder.

A San Fernando Valley man who allegedly attacked a man in a red hat bearing the slogan "Make America Great Again" written in Russian while in the restroom of a Hermosa Beach bar pleaded not guilty Thursday to three felony charges. David Delgado, 32, of Winnetka, is charged with one count each of assault by means of force likely to produce great bodily injury, battery with serious bodily injury and second-degree robbery, according to the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office. The criminal complaint also alleges that Delgado personally inflicted great bodily injury. Delgado allegedly approached a man using a restroom in the bar on Labor Day, asked the meaning of the Russian writing on the hat, then punched the victim repeatedly in the face, causing him to fall to the ground, according to Hermosa Beach Police Department Sgt. Robert Higgins. "The suspect continued to punch the victim and then stole the victim's hat and fled," according to Higgins. The man suffered serious injuries, according to prosecutors. Using surveillance video and other "investigative resources," Hermosa Beach police investigators identified the suspect and arrested him Oct. 1 at his home in the Winnetka area without further incident, Higgins said. Delgado could face up to nine years in state prison if convicted as charged, according to the District Attorney's Office. City News Service

Central Catholic High School's guidance counselor is being accused of selling heroin from her Forest Hills apartment. Forest Hills police have charged Kelly Scherer, 36, with conspiracy, two counts of possession of a controlled substance, two counts of possession with the intent to deliver and two counts of prohibited acts. According to KDKA , Scherer, the counselor at the Oakland private school, is accused of dealing heroin and selling it to an undercover police officer. According to WPXI , police found about 150 needles and at least 50 stamp bags of suspected heroin in her Sumner Avenue apartment at the time of her arrest. A statement released from Central Catholic said Scherer had been suspended due to "unsatisfactory job performance" and was not acting as the school's counselor at the time of her arrest. Scherer also is facing a Jan. 22 non-jury trial in the Allegheny County Common Pleas Court on a felony count of false/fraudulent medical assistance claim filed by the state attorney general's office,  according to the Post Gazette . Scherer currently is being held at the Allegheny County Jail. Her bail has been set at $25,000. As of Friday evening, she had not posted bail, according to court documents. A preliminary hearing before District Justice Thomas Caulfield has been scheduled for Dec. 5 at 9 a.m.

The Irmo Police Department has issued arrest warrants for a man who led officers on a chase through Lexington and Richland counties Tuesday morning. Quintin Lafayette Garrett of Richcreek Road in Columbia has been identified as the man accused of leading authorities on a chase after he was stopped by an officer on Lake Murray Boulevard around 9:30 a.m. Tuesday, Irmo Police Chief Brian Buck said.  Garrett faces charges of driving under suspension, failure to stop for blue lights and seatbelt violation. Police say Garrett, who was driving a black Mitsubishi Galant, drove away from the traffic stop and led officers on a chase from Lake Murray Boulevard to Broad River Road and Zimalcrest Drive, then to Interstate 26 and I-20 before getting off on SC 277 in Northeast Columbia.  Buck said Garrett abandoned the car between mile markers 3 and 4. No one was injured and no vehicles were damaged during the chase, the department said. Garrett is described as a black male, 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 200 pounds. If you have any information about the suspect, contact Crimestoppers at 1-888-CRIME-SC.

A West Springfield High School teacher is accused of inappropriate conversations with a teen, according to the Fairfax County Police. Laurence Einuis, 53, of the 8400 block of Great Lake Lane, Springfield, is charged with use of communications systems to facilitate certain offenses involving children. On Monday, officers began investigating an alleged inappropriate conversation with a 14-year-old boy. The boy was not harmed, according to police. Einuis was arrested Thursday at West Springfield High School without incident. According to WJLA,  Einuis was a band director at the school . Anyone with information in the case can call Crime Solvers by phone at 1-866-411-TIPS/8477, e-mail at www.fairfaxcrimesolvers.org  or text "TIP187" plus your message to CRIMES/274637 or call Fairfax County Police at 703-691-2131 .

A suspected serial sex offender from Encino was charged Friday with assaulting or groping five women in the San Fernando Valley this year, including two real estate agents during open houses. Authorities are asking potential additional victims to come forward. Alen Karaboghosian, 45, is set to be arraigned Friday afternoon in a Van Nuys courtroom on one felony count of assault with intent to commit rape and four misdemeanor counts of sexual battery. Detective believe Karaboghosian is the man caught on security footage in a brazen attack of a realtor at an Encino open house last week. Karaboghosian allegedly attacked a real estate agent in Encino last Sunday after she showed him a home that was listed for sale, according to Deputy District Attorney Brendan Sullivan. The defendant allegedly pushed the woman to the ground in an attempt to sexually assault her, Investigators identified Karaboghosian as the suspect as a result of "critical information received from the public" after security video of the attack was released, according to the Los Angeles Police Department. Karaboghosian is also accused of groping another real estate agent during an open house and three other women on public streets in four previous incidents dating back to February, according to the prosecutor. Plainclothes investigators from the LAPD's Gang and Narcotics Division participated in a surveillance operation that led to Karaboghosian's arrest at about 1:30 a.m. Wednesday. He could face up to eight years in state prison if he is convicted as charged, according to the District Attorney's Office. City News Service and Patch Staffer Paige Austin contributed to this report.

A 25-year-old Woodstock resident has been arrested for shooting another person outside a home over the weekend. Deputies with the Cherokee Sheriff's Office were dispatched to a call of a person shot around 9:44 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13 at a home on River Laurel Way, which is located off Arnold Mill Road near Hickory Flat Highway.  Deputies arrived at the residence and located the victim, who suffered a gunshot wound to the face. That person was transported to an area hospital for treatment and is in stable condition, said sheriff's office spokesperson Sgt. Marianne Kelley.  Deputies canvassed the area and spoke with witnesses to the incident. During the initial investigation, it was revealed an altercation in the front yard of the home resulted in the victim being shot in the face, Sgt. Kelley said. The agency's Criminal Investigation Divisions continued to work the case, and Michael Monterio was identified as the suspect. Monterio was arrested Monday, Jan. 15 and charged with aggravated assault, aggravated battery and discharging a firearm near a road. He's being held at the Cherokee County Adult Detention Center without bond.  When asked what led to the alternation and how the victim and alleged perpetrator knew each other, Sgt. Kelley told Patch that information is part of the ongoing investigation.  Photo: Michael Monterio. Credit: Cherokee Sheriff's Office

An Apple Valley man accused of stealing nearly $3,000 in Blu-Ray discs from an Eagan Target allegedly told police he planned to sell the stolen items to help his family "make ends meet." Scott Thomas Hodge, 33, a single count of felony theft, according to a criminal complaint filed by the Dakota County Attorney's Office. If convicted, Hodge could face a maximum of five years in prison and $10,000 in fines. On May 7, police were called to the Target in Eagan on a shoplifting report. Officers located the suspect, Hodge, upon arrival, and allegedly found a large quantity of Blu-Ray movies hidden in a diaper bag. Police also spoke with a store employee, who told officers that the value of the stolen Blu-Rays was $969.66. It wasn't the first time Hodge had stolen from the store, the employee told police. On April 26 and May 2, the employee said, Hodge also made off with a hefty number of Blu-Rays. The first theft was valued at $1,189.67, and the May 2 loss was $712.83, for a total loss between the three incidents of $2,872.16. Police say Hodge admitted to stealing the merchandise. Hodge told officers that his family was facing a difficult financial situation and that he planned to sell the stolen goods to "make ends meet," according to the criminal complaint.

The Manchester Police Department is asking for the public's help after an alleged armed robbery in the Queen City two nights ago. According to police, at just before 8:15 p.m. on Nov. 13, 2017, officers were sent to a robbery report at the N & N Express at 230 Lowell St. A man – unknown to the store clerk – reportedly entered the store and then, tried to buy a single beer with a credit card, according to Lt. Brian O'Keefe of the Manchester Police Department. Editor's Note:  This post was derived from information supplied by the Manchester Police Department. It does not indicate a conviction. A man accused of killing a Golden resident, then stealing his truck and guns, fleeing to Salt Lake City and and gunning down a Chinese student, pleaded guilty to murder and kidnapping charges. Austin Jeffery Boutain, 24, entered guilty pleas Wednesday in Utah for an agreement that would avoid a possible death penalty. He was sentenced to life without parole. Austin Boutain, and his wife, Kathleen Elizabeth Rose Boutain, 23, were accused of  carjacking a vehicle owned by Chenwei Guo , a University of Utah  student from Beijing,  and then killing him in October of 2017. Kathleen Boutain  is charged with criminal solicitation and theft, the Associated Press reported. She has not entered a plea. The two were drifters who showed up in Golden before they went to Utah. The  Boutains allegedly got into an argument with 63-year old Mitchell Bradford Ingle  while staying in his RV trailer at Clear Creek RV Park, 1401 10th St. Bradford was murdered and the Boutains are accused of  stealing his pickup truck and several guns and making their way to Salt Lake City. The Boutains face murder and theft charges in Colorado. A Michigan man is accused of hiding a camera so he could spy on workers as they used the employee restroom at the Mount Pleasant bank branch where he was the manager. David Prawdzik, 55, of Clare will be arraigned Aug. 21 on charges of capturing/distributing an image of an unclothed person, tampering with evidence, eavesdropping and using a computer to commit a crime,  the Detroit Free Press reports . Prawdzik, the branch manager at the Chemical Bank branch in Mount Pleasant, allegedly admitted to police he began planting cameras a few weeks ago "to capture video of 'his girls' at the bank," according to an affidavit filed with the criminal complaint against Prawdzik,  The Morning Sun reports . Police arrested Prawdzik, who had worked at the bank for 33 years, Thursday after an employee found the camera hidden in a toilet paper roll stashed at the rear of the toilet stall. The employee and other co-workers showed the camera Prawdzik, who reportedly "became quite distressed and threw the camera in the toilet," according to the affidavit. When he was made his initial court appearance Friday, Isabella County Trial Magistrate Sandra Straus, Prawdzik said he likely wouldn't be employed by the bank "after today." Citing his probable job loss and concern about his mental state, Straus set his bond at 10 percent of $50,000. Prawdzik reportedly told the judge that he will be OK.

Felony charges were filed today against a photographer and children's tumbling teacher accused of sexually assaulting a teenage girl and being in possession of child pornography.  Christopher A. Brown, 42, of Orange, was arrested last Friday at a Newport Beach shopping center and held in lieu of $500,000 bail, according to Orange County sheriff's Lt. Jeff Hallock.  He's scheduled to be arraigned today on felony charges of possession of child pornography, sexual penetration by a foreign object of an underage victim, committing a lewd or lascivious act with a minor and forcible oral copulation.  Investigators suspect there may be more alleged victims, as Brown also teaches private tumbling lessons for children and has traveled the country working as a freelance photographer, Hallock said.  Investigators recovered hundreds of child porn photos and videos when a search warrant was executed at a hotel in Irvine where Brown had been staying, Hallock alleged. Investigators recovered hundreds of child porn photos and videos when a search warrant was executed at a hotel in Irvine where Brown had been staying, he said. Brown has a conviction in 2005 in Virginia for possession of child pornography, and failed to register as a sex offender in California when he moved into the state several years ago, according to Hallock.  Detectives suspect Brown targets teenage girls, the lieutenant said. Anyone aware of adolescents Brown may have victimized was urged to call the sheriff's department at (714) 647-7418. Bond has been set at $100,000 for a 44-year-old Highwood man accused of sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman he worked with, police said. Victor Manuel Martinez-Lopez, of the 300 block of Ashland Avenue, is charged with unlawful restraint and criminal sexual assault, both felony charges, and battery, a misdemeanor charge, according to a news release from the Vernon Hills Police Department. Authorities launched an investigation into the sexual assault after a father called police to report that he allegedly observed Martinez-Lopez pin his daughter against the wall of the restaurant where both worked in the 1200 block of South Milwaukee Avenue in Vernon Hills.  The father said the man then kissed the 19-year-old woman, according to the news release. The incident occurred on April 14 and the father reported the alleged sex assault to police two days later.  Investigators worked closely with officials from the Lake County Children Advocacy Center to conduct an extensive investigation into the incident, police said.  "The investigation revealed that the reported incident involved the suspect committing a sexual assault on the victim," according to the news release.  Martinez-Lopez was arrested on May 2 at a different place of employment in Highland Park and was taken to the Vernon Hills Police Department, police said. Bond was set at $100,000 during a hearing on Thursday.  He is next expected in court on May 29.  Photo via Shutterstock

An 18-year-old Rolling Meadows high school student is accused of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old girl last month. Kendrick McKissack  was charged  Tuesday with criminal sexual assault stemming from the incident, the Daily Herald reports. According to prosecutors, McKissack and the girl met outside his apartment building March 24, a day after the two had met and given each other their phone numbers, the report stated. The two then went upstairs to the apartment after McKissack said he'd forgotten something, the report added. Once in the apartment, prosecutors claim McKissack allegedly tried to take off the girl's clothes, but she stopped him, the report stated. After he was rebuffed, McKissack is accused of pinning her on a mattress and sexually assaulting her, the report added. Prosecutors said the girl discovered she was pregnant nearly a month following the incident, the report stated. The girl then told her mother about the alleged attack, and McKissack was arrested the same day, the report added. McKissack was released on an individual recognizance bond, and he is next day in court is May 17. More via the Daily Herald Photo via Shutterstock

A 69-year-old woman was attacked three separate times last month while on a walk in suburban Aurora, ABC7 reported, and police are looking for the suspect. ABC7 reported she was out on her usual morning walk, between 5:50 a.m. and 6:01 a.m., near Rural and Ohio when she was approached from behind. The suspect demanded valuables. When she told him she didn't have any, she was allegedly pushed to the ground and kicked in the face. Police say the suspect then came back and battered her again before running away. The victim knocked on a nearby door asking for help, but nobody answered. The suspect then returned again,  attacking her once more  before running northbound on Ohio. She then knocked on another door in the 900 block of Mountain Street, where the owner answered and called the police for her. Paramedics checked her out at the scene, ABC7 reported, but she refused to go to the hospital. She described the suspect as a black male around 20 years old, about 5-foot-1 and weighed around 150 pounds. Anybody with information is urged to call the Aurora police at 630-256-5500, or call CrimeStoppers at 630-892-1000. CrimeStoppers calls are anonymous and may yield a reward up to $5,000 if the information leads to an arrest. Article image via Shutterstock

A 33-year-old Yorkville man who was arrested Friday, March 11 for exposing himself to a female jogger is believed to be the  same man who committed a similar crime  in late February.  Christopher A. Assmar, of the 300 block of Orange Street, was charged with one felony count of public indecency and one misdemeanor count of the same offense, Oswego Police Department Public Information Officer Cathy Nevara said in a press release.  At around 1 p.m. March 11, a female jogger called police after a male driver reportedly asked her for directions and exposed himself at Bloomfield Circle East and Colchester Drive.  The incident is nearly identical to the one that occurred two weeks ago  and the description of the man matched what was given before, according to Nevara.  During the investigation, detectives identified Assmar as a possible suspect and made contact with him at his home, where he was subsequently arrested at around 5:45 p.m., Nevara said.  Police believe Assmar is the same man who exposed himself in the Feb. 27 incident. In that instance, Assmar also allegedly called out to two children, who ignored him and ran away, according to Nevara. Assmar's felony charge of public indecency stems from children being involved, Nevara said.  Bail has been set at 10 percent of $10,000.  The Oswego Police Department is continuing to investigate these incidents. Anyone who may be able to provide further information should call the Oswego Police Department at 630-551-7300 or Kendall County Crime Stoppers at 630-553-5999.

Fairfax City Police have arrested an Alexandria woman, now a former employee, of a local nursing center for allegedly stealing and pawning jewelry from patients, police said in their daily crime report released Wednesday. Police say that the woman stole jewelry from patients at  Fairfax Nursing Center , located at 10701 Main St. in Fairfax. Police did not give descriptions of the jewelry or say whether it was recovered. The now-former employee, Mariama Wandu, 35, of Alexandria, met with officers at police headquarters Feb. 24 and was taken into custody and transported to the Adult Detention Center, police said. Her bond was set at $5,000. Wandu was charged with three counts of grand larceny and three counts of larceny with intent to sell, after investigators found that stolen items had been taken to pawn shops. The City police department's Patrol and Criminal Investigations Division identified Wandu as a suspect after investigating thefts of jewelry from patients between August 30-Jan. 12, police said. PHOTO: Fairfax Nursing Center photo from fairfaxnursingcenter.com

A $10,000 reward is being offered for information leading to the arrest and conviction of a man suspected of at least 13 bank robberies across five states since December 2016. Known among law enforcement agencies as the "Double Hat Bandit," the man is accused of four bank robberies in Oregon alone, including three in the Portland metro area, two of which occurred at the same location in Portland six months apart.  So called due to his penchant for wearing a beanie over a baseball cap during his robberies, the Double Hat Bandit typically hits bank branches located inside grocery stores, according to the FBI, which is also the agency offering the reward. (Metro Denver Crime Stoppers is offering a separate reward of $2,000.)  During the robberies, FBI officials said, the Double Hat Bandit gave bank tellers a note demanding cash, and during at least four of the robberies he displayed a handgun in his waistband.  The most recent robbery attributed to the Double Hat Bandit occurred on July 22 at the U.S. Bank located at 7100 W. State St. in Boise, Idaho. The 12 other robberies for which he is accused are:  Following the June 27 robbery in Spokane, which was the second time he allegedly robbed that particular bank branch, the Double Hat Bandit was seen escaping in a grayish-blue Malibu-style car with New Mexico license plates, FBI officials said. Law enforcement agencies in Utah, Washington, Oregon, Colorado, and Idaho are searching for the Double Hat Bandit. Anyone with information regarding this suspect is encouraged to call the FBI tipline at 801-579-6480. Photo Courtesy: FBI — Oregon

Denver police and Crime Stoppers announced today that an anonymous donor has boosted a reward offered for information about a man accused of sexually assaulting a woman in her home in a mid-day attack. A reward of $5,000 is now being offered for information leading to the arrest of Jerome Lekendric Lucas, 34, who is facing possible charges of sex assault, kidnapping and burglary. Police said on March 24, Lucas allegedly entered a woman's house on a Sunday afternoon and sexually assaulted her, then stole several items from her home, including her car, which has been recovered.  "The nature of this crime [including] burglary and sex assault on a Sunday afternoon in broad daylight, is not anything I have been a part of in my 16-year career," said Detective Lang of the Denver Police Sex Crimes Unit. "We need to get him off the streets. He is a danger to the community." Lucas has a long criminal history including theft, assault, burglary, drug and weapons possession, and car theft, police said. Lucas has changed his appearance several times, but has distinctive face and neck tattoos, police said.  He may have left Denver and has connections in South Dakota, California, Texas and Missouri, Lang said. To send in a tip and possibly win the award, call Metro Denver Crime Stoppers 720-913-STOP (7867).

A Cabazon man accused of attacking his mother and holding her against her will must stand trial on charges of assault, false imprisonment and dissuading a witness, a judge ruled Thursday. Richard Anthony Diaz, 32, was arrested March 20 following the alleged assault that took place in the 14000 block of Marino Street. Diaz's mother -- a 54-year-old woman referred to only as Jane Doe in court documents -- went to the Cabazon sheriff's station at 9:42 a.m. that day to allege that her son had assaulted her, Riverside County Sheriff's Sgt. John Carlberg said. Diaz was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder, but prosecutors filed a lesser charge of assault with a deadly weapon against him, along with the false imprisonment count. The deadly weapon was the defendant's hands, according to the criminal complaint. Prosecutors later amended the charges to assault on a person causing great bodily injury and added a felony count of dissuading a witness. Diaz remains free on $25,000 bail after being released from custody on March 24. He's slated to return to court on Aug. 16 for a post-preliminary hearing arraignment. The Atlanta Police Department arrested a man suspected of murder within 48 hours of the alleged crime, according to a Facebook post by the department. Wendell Ross was arrested and charged with the murder of Leslie Bell, who was stabbed to death, police say. On Tuesday, Oct. 29, police were called to a house on Willis Mill Road SW on a woman on the floor bleeding. Police arrived to find Bell laying on the kitchen floor with stab wounds to her throat. She was pronounced dead at the scene. Then, on Wednesday, police investigators found probable cause and got a search warrant for Ross' house. Police say that Ross confessed to the murder during an interrogation. He was taken into custody and to the Fulton County Jail, charged with murder.

A local teen was arrested yesterday after allegedly shooting a girl in an apartment on West Street, according to a police report. Damian Walsh, 18, of Manchester, was arrested on March 21, 2015, and charged with reckless conduct. According to police, officers were sent to West Street for a report of a shooting. When they arrived at the apartment, they found a girl who had been shot and suffered serious but non-life threatening injuries. She was later transported to Catholic Medical Center where she remains in serious condition. Officers conducted an investigation and learned that Walsh was a suspect. Throughout the morning, they were worked the case and were able to find Walsh, who was arrested.  Police are looking for the public's help with the case. If you have any information about Walsh or the girl, please call Manchester Police at 603-668-8711 or leave a tip on Crimeline at 603-624-4040. Editor's note:  This post was derived from information supplied by the Manchester Police Department. It does not indicate a conviction. A DuPage County judge lowered the bail for a Cicero woman accused of losing control of her car, driving into an Aurora retention pond, and leaving her son inside. Gladys Ruvira-Garcia's bail was originally set at $500,000 after the accident, but Judge Liam Brennan reduced it to $150,000. Ruvira-Garcia currently has a hold placed on her by Immigrations Custom and Enforcement because she allegedly entered the United States with an expired visa.  Ruvira-Garcia's family, many of whom were present in court during the hearing, was able to raise $10,000, according to Chicago Tribune. If she's able to post 10% of the reduced bond, ICE may issue a warrant for her arrest on the grounds of the alleged immigration violation, Chicago Tribune reports.  Brennan made the decision to lower Ruvira-Garcia's bail after her attorney's asserted that her clean criminal record should be taken into account.  Ruvira-Garcia was arrested after her car spun out of control and landed in a retention pond while she was on her way back to Cicero from a party she attended with her son and other women and teens from her family. The females were able to escape, but  Ruvira-Garcia's son  was left trapped inside the immersed vehicle.  After the accident, police said Ruvira-Garcia's BAC was .14, nearly twice the legal limit.  She plead not guilty to four counts of aggravated driving under the influence.  Ruvira-Garcia's son, who was trapped in the car, is still hospitalized, her attorneys told Chicago Tribune. He had been on a ventilator and is expected to have permanent brain damage.  >>Image via DuPage County State's Attorney's Office >>More via Chicago Tribune

A man and woman accused of committing an armed robbery at an East Granby convenience store Wednesday afternoon were taken into custody shortly thereafter by Bloomfield police officers and a Connecticut State Police trooper. Around 2:15 p.m., a clerk at the NH Deli and Grocery convenience store at 95 Spoonville Road reported being robbed by a man wielding a knife. Investigation revealed the suspect and an unknown woman left the scene in a dark-colored pickup truck, a state police report says. A description of the vehicle and suspects was broadcast to police in surrounding towns, and the truck was stopped in Bloomfield and the pair arrested, according to the report. Thomas Phillips, 50, of Windsor, was charged with first-degree robbery, second-degree reckless endangerment, second-degree criminal mischief and sixth-degree larceny. Alisha Phillips, 24, of East Windsor, was charged with criminal attempt to commit first-degree robbery and interfering with an officer. Bond for each was set at $50,000, and arraignment is scheduled for Thursday in Enfield Superior Court. State police spokesperson Kelly Grant said the relationship between the two is not yet known. Photos courtesy of Connecticut State Police

A Macungie man is in Northampton County Prison following his arrest for his alleged involvement in an attempted street robbery in South Bethlehem in October. Brian M. Reiss, 29, of 3976 Orchard Road, was arraigned Thursday on charges of felony robbery, simple assault and criminal conspiracy in front of , who set bail at $100,000. He and co-defendant Stephen M. Smith of 47 S. Fifth St., Emmaus, are accused of following two victims out of , a bar and restaurant at 217 Broadway on October 3. According to court papers, Reiss and Smith caught up to their two targets on the 400 block of Birkel Avenue, accosted them and demanded that they empty their pockets and give them all of their money. They then lunged at their two targets, both men, and began to fight with them. Reiss and Smith then fled when Lehigh University police arrived near the scene.

A registered sex offender from Austell has been arrested after he allegedly took apart the charger in his electronic monitoring device. Kenneth Leonard Keith is currently classified as a "sexually dangerous predator" and is required to wear the ankle monitor, according to a Cobb County criminal warrant. The ankle monitor and charger "have been replaced numerous times in the past," an officer wrote in the warrant. During an inspection of the charger, authorities Thursday "discovered that the charger had been taken apart and had what appeared to be black electrical tape wrapped around the wires," the officer wrote. "Accused admitted that he did take the charger apart and did tape the wires with the tape. Accused is currently out on bond for the same prior conduct." Keith was arrested on a charge of removal or destruction of electronic monitoring devices. He is in the Cobb County Adult Detention Center without bond.

The Cherokee Sheriff's Office has issued arrest warrants for a 19-year-old man accused of stealing from vehicles in the Acworth area late last month.  Demone Ontray Allen is suspected of entering at the vehicles of two victims Aug. 30 in the Centennial Lakes subdivision and taking items such as a laptop, credit cards and a firearm, sheriff's office spokesperson Jay Baker said.  Detectives have learned those stolen credit cards were used at establishments in Kennesaw and at shops in Atlantic Station. On Friday, Aug. 31, Allen was arrested and charged by Atlanta police following a chase of a stolen vehicle. That vehicle, Backer added, included several items stolen from victims in Cherokee County.    Allen was charged by Atlanta police with theft by receiving, entering auto, prowling, obstruction, possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime, fleeing and attempting to elude police and criminal damage to property in the second degree. He was booked into the Fulton County Jail on Sept. 1, and released on bond the same day. Baker said that release occurred before Cherokee sheriff's investigators learned of the incident.  Allen, of Lithonia, is wanted in Cherokee County on burglary, entering auto, felony theft by taking, misdemeanor theft by taking, financial card theft and financial card fraud charges. He is described as a black male about 5 feet, 8 inches tall, roughly 145 pounds and has short black hair. Anyone who has information on his whereabouts is asked to call 911.  Image via Fulton County Jail

Joaquin Mendez, 27 | Cook County Sheriff SUMMIT, IL -- A 27-year-old fence installer is accused of beating his pregnant girlfriend unconscious and battling cops during a domestic battery call, prosecutors said Monday in court. Joaquin Mendez, 27, appeared before Cook County Judge Peter Felice on charges of aggravated domestic battery, five counts of aggravated battery to a police officer, two misdemeanor counts of resisting arrest, misdemeanor assault and misdemeanor criminal damage to property. Summit police responded to a domestic disturbance call around 4:20 p.m. April 17. According to the charges, Mendez and his girlfriend, who is 22 weeks pregnant, had gotten into a verbal argument that escalated into physical altercation. During the fight, Mendez allegedly kneed the pregnant woman multiple times in the stomach and beat her unconscious. She was taken to MacNeal Hospital in Berwyn where she received five staples in her hairline and treatment for a black eye and scratches on her arms, the prosecutor said. Police said Mendez was verbally combative when they tried to take him into custody. During the arrest, police said Mendez physically fought them and spit blood at an officer.  Later, the prosecutor said, Mendez apologized to police and told them he was intoxicated. The assistant public defender told the judge that Mendez was a 27-year-old high school graduate and employed as a fence installer. Judge Felice set bail at $250,000. He ordered Mendez to stay from his girlfriend. "If I find out you called her from jail, you will stay in jail," Felice said. Mendez is due back in court May 6 in Bridgeview.

Fremont Police officers arrested a 15-year-old teen, accused of armed robbery on the campus of Irvington High School on Thursday of last week. The arrest was made Wednesday morning in the 4600 block of Norwood Terrace in the Irvington district. Police also recovered what they believe was the weapon used in the crime , described as a replica gun. The boy is not a current student in the Fremont Unified School District. His name is being withheld because of his age. >>Previous:  Gunman Robs 2 at Fremont High School The robbery happened Jan. 12 just after 8 p.m. According to police, "An adult male and male juvenile were standing behind the gym when they were robbed by a male suspect. The suspect, described as a male juvenile, initially walked past the two and then turned around and displayed a weapon and demanded their wallets." The adult handed over his wallet. Police and a K9 searched the area until almost 10 p.m., but the suspect wasn't found. The stolen wallet was recovered on campus. "Officers stayed with the students who were at their club meetings and basketball team practice until parents arrived," police report. If you have information on this case, contact Officer Dennis at  Adennis@fremont.gov  or call Investigations at 510-790-6900.  — Image by Renee Schiavone, Patch

STUYVESANT, BROOKLYN — A Bed-Stuy woman stands accused of fatally stabbing her boyfriend in the neck Sunday morning, according to police and reports.  Octavia Elliot, 31, allegedly stabbed Ramel Patterson, 33, in her home on Pulaski Street near Stuyvesant Avenue around 3:30 a.m. Sunday, police said.  Emergency responders, who found Patterson with two stab wounds on his throat and arm, rushed the unconscious man to Kings County Hospital, but doctors were unable to save his life, said police.  Elliot was taken in for questioning shortly after the stabbing and was charged with murder Sunday afternoon, police said.  Elliot, who was in a relationship with Bushwick man, threw a bloody knife out the window of her fifth-floor apartment that was later found by investigating officers, a police source told am New York.  The police source also told am New York that Elliot has  10 prior arrests that include allegations the she used a screwdriver to stab her child's father  in the hand, face and back in 2013.  Court records show her arraignment in Brooklyn Criminal Court was pending as of Monday morning. Photo courtesy of GoogleMaps/Nov. 2016

Both were arrested. -- East Haven Police are seeking two suspects, one male and one female, from an elderly resident's home during an apparent roof repair scam. -- A Stratford man has been for stealing more than $14,000 worth of jewelry from a Naugatuck home on Oct. 2, 2011. Since February, Douglas Fast, 47, has also been charged by police in seven other towns for similar crimes, according to state records. He has 26 burglary and larceny cases pending in state courthouses.  -- A Hamden car dealer is accused of .
