INWOOD, NY — Five members of a gang that operated for years in Northern Manhattan were indicted on robbery, narcotics and firearms charges following a recent takedown, federal prosecutors said. Prosecutors also linked the gang to a 2014 murder, but have yet to take the accused shooting into custody. Milton Chardon, Bryan Castillo, George Citronelle, Noel Martinez and Juan Calderon were arrested this week and hit with charges including racketeering, conspiracy to deal narcotics, robbery, burglarizing pharmacies and firearms offenses, federal prosecutors announced. One other accused gang member, Yasmil Fertides was already in custody, prosecutors said. The men allegedly committed crimes between 2011 and 2018 in the name of the 200 Gang, federal prosecutors said. The gang was allegedly behind the 2014 murder of Orlando Rivera, who was shot in front of a building on St. Nicholas Avenue, but the accused gunman Christian Pabon was not taken into custody during the gang bust, federal prosecutors said. "The defendants wreaked havoc on their northern Manhattan neighborhood for years through a litany of crimes that harmed local businesses, injured robbery victims, and killed an innocent man," U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York Geoffrey Berman said in a statement. In addition to the 2014 murder, gang members were also accused of an attempted murder in 2015 on Sherman Avenue and a 2016 shooting on Academy Street and Nagle Avenue, federal prosecutors said. The gang also ran a burglary operation targeting pharmacies in the Washington Heights and Inwood neighborhoods as well as in the Bronx.  The six gang members in custody are expected to be arraigned in federal court on Sept. 21, prosecutors said. Photo by Renee Schiavone/Patch

Police have arrested a man in connection with the sexual assault of four women in Reston 22 years ago. Florida authorities arrested 49-year-old Jude Joseph David Lovchik near his home in Ocala, Fla., last Wednesday. He is accused of sexually assaulting four women in an apartment in the 11000 block of Olde Tiverton Circle in Reston back on June 6, 1995, according to a  report  from the Fairfax County Police Department. Police got a major break in the case on Aug. 25, when DNA evidence "confirmed an investigative lead our detectives had been pursuing," the report states. Using that evidence along with additional information uncovered by detectives, they identified Lovchik as a suspect. Lovchick used to reside in Springfield before he moved to Florida in September. Lovchik faces a host of serious charges. He's been charged with fugitive from justice, and he will eventually be charged with armed burglary, abduction with intent to defile, and sodomy, police say. He is expected to face those additional charges once extradited back to Fairfax County, and more charges could be coming. "The team of men and woman who have been working this case have put in a tremendous amount of work," Capt. David Smith of the Fairfax County Police Major Crimes Bureau said in the report. "As a result of their dedication, we have taken this predator off the street." Police ask anyone with additional information on Lovchik, including other potential victims, to call 703-246-4623. Image via FCPD

A Morris Plains man was arrested for allegedly calling in threats to a college in Washington state last month, Morris County Prosecutor Fredrick M. Knapp said in a statement. Robert W. Kerekes Jr., 53, is accused of calling in threats to Evergreen State College in Olympia, Washington on June 2. As a result, the college was shut down on June 2 and June 3, Knapp said. State and local law enforcement in Washington responded to the college during the threats, according to Knapp. Kerekes allegedly called the Thurston County, Washington 911 center on June 1 and said:  Evergreen State has been the focus of conservative and leftist activists recently. Each year, the college hosts a "day of absence" for students and faculty of color; the day is meant to symbolize how important people of color are to the campus. This year, campus activists instead asked white students and faculty to leave campus. In response, Bret Weinstein, a biology instructor, wrote an email calling the request "an act of oppression" against whites. Weinstein later appeared on Tucker Carlson's show on Fox News to defend himself. Other conservative media outlets picked up the story as an example of on-campus censorship. Aside from the death threats, hate symbols like swastikas began appearing on campus,  according to The Stranger . Kereks is charged with crimes of terroristic threats, criminal cohersion, and false public alarm. He is being held in the Morris County Correctional Facility. Additional reporting by  Neal McNamara (Patch Staff) Image via Creative Commons

A 20-year-old USC student was arrested Tuesday for allegedly committing a sexual assault in a campus dorm. Authorities identified the suspect as Armann Karim Premjee. He is suspected of committing the sexual assault on April 1, according to the Los Angeles Police Department. No other details about the crime or the victim were released. Premjee was being held in lieu of $100,000 bail, according to sheriff's inmate records. City News Service; Photo:  Padsquad19  via Wikimedia Commons

UPDATED: 8 p.m. One of two men wanted in connection with a suspected methamphetamine lab in Northeast Bethlehem that exploded and caught fire turned himself Thursday morning, Bethlehem police said. Jeffrey Caulfield, 28, is the third person connected with the alleged meth lab at 1965 Greenleaf St. to be arrested. Police have a warrant for Caulfield in which he is charged with operating a meth lab, criminal conspiracy, causing a catastrophe and five other crimes. Police have already arrested the house's owner, Elaine M. Noone, 64, and one alleged accomplice, 39, of  Palmer Township . Caulfield was arraigned before District Judge James Narlesky in Hanover Township and then committed to Northampton County Prison in lieu of $100,000 bail. A fourth alleged co-conspirator, Daniel James Houser, 39, remains at large. On Tuesday, police released a photo of Houser. However, police noted that he no longer has a ponytail and has suffered burns to his face, lips, arms and right leg as a result of the March 8 explosion and fire at the alleged meth lab. Anyone with information about Houser's whereabouts is asked to call the Bethlehem Police Department at 610-865-7187 or Det. Christopher Vasvari at 610-865-7129. The explosion and fire happened about three hours before Bethlehem police planned to execute a search warrant at the house, which was obtained as a result of a two-month investigation into methamphetamine sales in the city and Bethlehem Township, police said. The home has been condemned by city officials.

Lewd acts with a minor and other felony charges were filed Friday against a Temecula man accused of molesting his 6-year-old relative. Dana Leon Wilber, 50, was arrested and booked Wednesday into the Byrd Detention Center in French Valley on suspicion of felony sex charges, with bail set at $1 million, records show. According to Riverside County sheriff's Sgt. Steve Fredericks, earlier this month, detectives received a report that Wilber had allegedly sexually abused the young victim, sparking an investigation. "The victim's mother immediately removed the suspect's access to the victim upon learning of the sexual abuse," Fredericks said in a news release.  Detectives conducted interviews and gathered evidence over a two-week span, eventually obtaining a warrant for Wilber's arrest. "On [Monday], detectives located the suspect at his place of employment in the city of Riverside and placed him under arrest," the sergeant said.  Wilber has no prior documented felony convictions. Court records show he was charged with one count of committing a lewd act with a child under 14 and two counts of engaging in oral copulation or sexual penetration with a child under 10. He was expected in court on Friday. — City News Service contributed to this report / Image via Riverside County Sheriff's Department

Five teenagers were arrested Saturday after they allegedly stole a bag from a woman at the Trumbull Mall and led police on a high speed chase in a stolen car on Rte. 25. Police say the incident began when a mall employee reportes someone stole a bag from her as she sat in her car during her lunch break.  Police say a 16-year-old Waterbury teen took the bag and ran into an awaiting BMW SUV, which was reported stolen out of New Canaan. Police say the SUV nearly hit several vehicles as it left the mall parking lot.  An off-duty Trumbull officer spotted the BMW, and another officer tried to stop it on Main Street into Bridgeport. The chase continued until Trumbull, Bridgeport and State Police were able to stop the car near the Daniels Farm Road exit.  Four of the suspects in the car were juveniles. Police also arrested 18-year-old Johnny Aspiliare of Hartford and charged him with larceny in the first degree, conspiracy to commit robbery and interfering with an officer. He was held on a $10,00 bond.  The four remaining teens were from Waterbury. Three were released to parents and a 16-year-old from Waterbury was found to have an active arrest warrant out of Waterbury and was turned over to that department.  The BMW and the teenagers are suspected to be involved in similar crimes, police said. That part of the investigation continues.

A Marietta man has been arrested after allegedly robbing a Wells Fargo bank in the city, Cobb police said Thursday. Officers were called to the bank around 12:30 p.m. Wednesday in the 2500 block of Dallas Highway in Marietta and made an arrest minutes later. Steven Randall McCall, 43, of Marietta is charged with armed robbery and three counts of aggravated assault, all felonies, according to Cobb police spokeswoman Alicia Chilton. ( To get notified of more local news like this, click here to  sign up for the Marietta Patch . Or  find your Atlanta -area town here .   Or, if you have an iPhone,  download the free Patch app . ) Investigators allege that McCall entered the bank and aimed a gun at bank tellers, demanding money. When the suspect got an undisclosed amount of cash, he fled the scene on foot.  The police department's Crimes Against Persons Unit is still investigating an armed robbery, she said. The incident follows a string of high-profile incidents at banks in recent days. Last week, a Marine caused a SWAT situation at a Wells Fargo on Windy Hill Road,  resulting in his death . Authorities are also looking for a woman whom they say has  stuck up several banks  in the metro area, including one in East Cobb. Image via Cobb Sheriff's Office

A local woman is accused of stealing more than $500,000 from a borough restaurant she worked for over the course of four years. Jung M. Yun, 36, of Palisades Park was charged with theft and money laundering after she was a arrested Thursday, said acting Bergen County Prosecutor Dennis Calo. The prosecutor's office Financial Crimes Unit received a complaint in April from the owner of a Fort Lee restaurant about suspected theft from the business by the manager, Yun, Calo said. The owner discovered that more than $500,000 was stolen from the business from 2014 to 2018 during a recent audit, Calo said. Yun was hired in 2014. Authorities learned that Yun allegedly used the restaurant's point of sale system to get cash payments from customers and then change the sales receipts to make it look like the sales were cancelled, Calo said.  Yun also allegedly stole cash tips that were supposed to be given to the restaurant's servers and bus staff, Calo said. Yun was arrested and lodged in the Bergen County Jail Annex pending a first appearance in Bergen County Superior Court, Calo said. Email  daniel.hubbard@patch.com . A 53-year-old man with more than 30 prior felony bookings was arrested on suspicion of residential burglary for allegedly breaking into someone's home Thursday at an apartment complex in El Segundo. "It appears the suspect jumped over a security fence surrounding the apartment complex and began checking for unlocked doors to apartments," Hawthorne police Sgt. Vince Martinez said. "After checking several doors, he found one unlocked and went inside." Officers dispatched at 12:12 a.m. to the 900 block of Main Street regarding a report of a man inside a resident's apartment reported that a resident was alone and asleep in his room, when he heard someone walk inside. The suspect rummaged through several items on a desk before lying down on the floor, Martinez said. Officers arrested the man, who was possibly a transient, on suspicion of residential burglary. The suspect, who may have engaged in other criminal activity in the area, has an extensive criminal history including more than 30 prior felony bookings, Martinez said. The suspect was described as black, 6-feet-1 inches tall and 145 pounds, and was wearing a white tank top and gray sweatpants at the time of his arrest. Hawthorne police asked anyone who might have any information about the suspect to call them at (310) 524-2261. --  City News Service. Photo courtesy of the El Segundo Police Department

Agents with the ATF don't file many criminal complaints at the Will County Courthouse but last week was an exception. The ATF, with assistance of Bolingbrook's Police Department, captured two men suspected of distributing a large amount of marijuana, as well as heroin. The criminal complaint charges co-defendants  Angel Cardenas-Rivera , 24, of Stickney, Illinois, and 27-year-old  Juan Romo  of Romoland, California, in Will County Circuit Court with unlawful delivery of a controlled substance, a class X felony, and unlawful possession of cannabis with intent to delivery, also a Class X felony. One criminal count alleges that Romo and Cardenas-Rivera, on June 5, "knowingly and unlawfully possessed with intent to deliver more than 5,000 grams of any substance containing cannabis." The second count alleges that back on Nov. 7, 2017, the pair "delivered 15 grams or more, but less than 100 grams of a substance containing heroin, a controlled substance." Patch reached out to Bolingbrook Police since Bolingbrook was listed at the jail as the arresting agency. However, Bolingbrook officials noted that they were only a secondary agency assisting on the case. In any event, Romo's bail was set by a Will County judge at $200,000 while Cardenas-Rivera got a $250,000 bail. Rivera has remained incarcerated since the early morning hours of June 6. Romo, on the other hand, posted bail on June 7 thanks to an uncle in Summit, Illinois, court records show. Mugshots of Angel Cardenas-Rivera and Juan Romo via Will County Sheriff

A Boston man accused of robbing multiple banks in communities on Route 128 is set to appear in court. Paul B. Landrum, dubbed the "Route 128 bandit," is scheduled to appear in U.S. District Court in Boston Friday at 10:15 a.m. On Wednesday, he was charged with bank robbery. Authorities say Landrum is responsible for nine bank robberies that took place in Greater Boston. In each case, witnesses described the suspect as a 30-45-year-old light-skinned black or Hispanic male wearing a baseball hat, sunglasses and a long-sleeved collarless shirt. Based on the descriptive similarities at each bank, law enforcement suspected that the same individual was involved in each robbery.  Landrum was arrested Oct. 24 after police were led to his get-away vehicle.  Laundrum faces up to 20 years in prison, three years of probation, and a $250,000 fine. Here's a full list of his alleged sightings: Image via FBI Boston

An alleged jewelry thief didn't do himself any favors when police said he hit the Barnstable Kmart then fled wearing an attention-grabbing cap that reads " SELFIE ." James Anderson, 65, allegedly stole $10,000 worth of gold jewelry Thursday night. He was arrested a few hours later after police said they used security camera footage to track him down. Police said Anderson is a career criminal, with a rap sheet that includes 78 criminal charges—mostly for theft and drugs. He was held in custody pending an arraignment Friday. Police said Anderson, who was wearing the "SELFIE" cap when he walked into Kmart, used wire cutters to remove the jewelry from a display case. An officer then pulled over his vehicle on Main Street and identified him as the theft suspect from the security camera footage. Anderson was still wearing the cap in the car, police said. The stolen jewelry was recovered.

Four men pulled over in a traffic stop connected to a drug heist were arrested Sunday night on suspicion of stealing more than 10 pounds of marijuana from a residence in Moraga.  A possible burglary was reported in the 100 block of Donald Drive just before 9:30 p.m., and the reporting party described the suspects as three or four men wearing hooded sweatshirts and armed with baseball bats. At least one of them was allegedly spotted with a gun. A suspect vehicle was identified and stopped in the vicinity of Moraga Road and Moraga Way. Responding officers found four men inside wearing hooded sweatshirts. They also allegedly found a baseball bat, a loaded handgun that turned out to be stolen, and a large quantity of marijuana  measured in excess of 10 pounds.  Investigators believe one of the suspects had purchased a large quantity of marijuana at the victim's residence at some point in the past, then returned with accomplices to steal more of it. None of the people inside the residence were injured. Police say that 21-year-old Emarieay Prescott, 20-year-old Domenico Delgado Caramagno and 20-year-old Thomas Lloyd III, all of whom are listed as Oakland residents, were arrested alongside 19-year-old Berkeley resident Azrael Vargas. They were booked into the Martinez Detention Facility on suspicion of crimes including robbery, burglary, conspiracy, possession of a firearm and probation violation. — Bay City News

At least three women reported being "flashed" while riding Orange County Transit Authority buses, recently. On Thursday, a 48-year-old Costa Mesa man was behind bars on charges of exposing himself. Three women, including a teenager, suffered the indignity of being "flashed" while riding OCTA buses across the county, and authorities suspect there may be additional victims. Carlos Alberto Tirado, who is charged with three misdemeanor counts of indecent exposure and a single misdemeanor count of child annoyance, was arrested June 29 and is being held in lieu of $35,000 bail, according to Orange County Jail records. He's next due in court July 13 for a pretrial hearing. About 1:30 p.m. on June 19, Orange County sheriff's deputies responded to a report that the suspect was exposing and touching himself on a bus near Highland and Bristol streets in Santa Ana while sitting near a 16-year-old girl, according to Carrie Braun of the Orange County Sheriff's Department. A sheriff's investigator reviewing bus surveillance footage recognized Tirado was a suspect arrested Feb. 20 for a similar flashing incident on an OCTA bus in Anaheim, Braun said. In that case, he allegedly exposed himself to a 22-year-old woman aboard a bus near State college Boulevard and La Palma Avenue, she said. He was arrested March 17 on suspicion of indecent exposure, but he bailed out of jail and was awaiting a court date at the time of the alleged June 29 crime, Braun said. Tirado is also accused of exposing and touching himself last Dec. 10 while making eye contact with a 22-year-old woman on an OCTA bus in Anaheim, she said. Sheriff's investigators asked anyone with information to call deputies at (714) 265-4340. Orange County Crime Stoppers accepts anonymous tips at (855) TIP-OCCS. Renee Schiavone Photo

A grand jury in Barnstable County has indicted the man accused of killing Yarmouth Police Officer Sean Gannon on multiple charges, including murder. Authorities say 29-year-old "career criminal" Thomas Latanowich shot and killed Gannon April 12 as Gannon, his K-9 Nero and six Barnstable and Yarmouth officers tried to arrest him at a Blueberry Lane residence in Marstons Mills.  Investigators believe Latanowich was hiding behind insulation in the attic of the home and shot Gannon and Nero after Gannon removed it. He then allegedly disassembled the gun and threw bullets in the toilet as officers closed in on him.  Latanowich ultimately surrendered to police. Gannon, who was shot in the head, was later pronounced dead at the hospital. Nero recovered from his injuries.  Latanowich had over 100 charges at the time of the killing. He has now been indicted on charges of murder, aggravated assault with a dangerous weapon, use of a firearm in the commission of a felony, possession of a firearm without a license and carrying a loaded weapon without a license, mistreating a police dog and armed career criminal,  according to 7-News .  Photo: Thomas Latanowich. (Credit: Yarmouth Police Department)

A Waterbury woman accused of committing various crimes against a 61-year-old handicapped Wilton resident, police said. Sequan Monice Francis, 23 was detained by State Police out of Troop A Nov. 29 after she was found inside the vehicle of a suspect accused of larceny that occurred earlier in the day in Danbury. Francis had an active arrest issued by the Wilton PD. Francis was taken into custody by the Southbury police department until Wilton officers arrived on scene. Francis was charged with second-degree identity theft, second-degree larceny and illegal use of a credit card.  She was held on a $10,000 court set bond and was expected to make her first court appearance Nov. 30.  Image via Wilton PD

A felon suspected of shooting a West Covina police officer last month was charged Wednesday with attempted murder of a peace officer. Jose R. Chavez, 47, is scheduled to be arraigned Thursday at the West Covina courthouse on the attempted murder charge, along with one felony count each of assault on a peace officer with a semiautomatic firearm and being a felon in possession of a firearm. The criminal complaint includes gun and gang allegations, along with an allegation that Chavez had been released from custody on bail or his own recognizance in a drug case. Chavez was arrested in La Puente just after 2 a.m. last Thursday by a sheriff's SWAT team and taken to a hospital to be treated for injuries he suffered in the May 20 gunbattle. He is accused of shooting West Covina police Officer Kenny Benitez in the upper body about 11:20 p.m. May 20 near the intersection of North Yaleton Avenue and Badillo Street. "Chavez fired numerous rounds at the officer as the officer attempted to detain him," Deputy Sara Rodriguez of the Sheriff's Information Bureau said last month. According to sheriff's homicide detectives assisting West Covina police with the officer-involved shooting investigation, Benitez had "contacted" a man riding a bicycle, which left to a gunfight between the officer and the cyclist, according to Deputy Trina Schrader. Benitez was hospitalized, but has since been released. It's unclear what led to the escalation after the initial contact was made by Benitez or why the officer initially stopped the man. -- City News Service, photo courtesy of the LASD

degree sexual assault for crimes that allegedly took place in the late 1990s, Acting Morris County Prosecutor Fredric Knapp announced Wednesday. Barry Miller, 42, is accused of engaging in "multiple acts of oral penetration" between February 1996 and February 1998 with a teen boy, Knapp said. The alleged victim was between the ages of 13 and 14-years-old during that time. The alleged victim told authorities he would be given alcohol and gifts in exchange for the sexual favors, Knapp said. Miller was arrested Tuesday, April 15 and transferred to Morris County, First Assistant Prosecutor Thomas Zelante said. Bail was set at $75,000 with no 10-percent option, set by Judge Maritza Berdote-Byrne. Miller is prohibited from having any contact with the victim and may not be near anyone under the age of 16 without supervision as a condition of his bail. Orland Park police arrested a woman they said stole wallets from customers at two different Panera Bread locations in the village over the last two months.  Star Davis, 47, of Chicago has been involved in "a litany of pick pocket thefts" from customers at the Panera locations, one at 15845 Harlem Ave. and the other at 15252 S. Lagrange Road.  Police said that on Feb. 13 Davis stole a wallet from a customer at the Harlem Avenue location and involved "several co-conspirators" in using the victim's credit cards at a Kohl's in Orland Park, a Target in Tinley Park and a Walmart in Orland Hills.  Davis is also accused of stealing a wallet from a customer at the Lagrange Road location on March 29 and using the co-conspirators to use the victim's credit cards at the Apple store in Orland Square Mall and the Target in Tinley Park.  The next day, Davis was arrested at her home in Chicago's West Englewood neighborhood. Police said she is "well known in the law enforcement community" for her involvement in pick pocket thefts and was on home monitoring at the time of her arrest. She was charged with continuing a criminal financial enterprise and identity theft.  A search of her residence recovered a wallet and credit cards taken in a theft at Panera the day prior, police said.  Davis is not the only pick pocket crew leader in the area, police warned. She is suspected in several other instances but has been ruled out in other cases.  Photo courtesy of Orland Park Police Department

Six felony charges of lewd acts on a child were filed Thursday against a 34-year-old East County man accused of sexually assaulting an underage girl. Shaun Crocker, also known as Shawn Hedge Crocker, according to a criminal complaint, is accused of touching the victim inappropriately on various occasions between September and November of last year. According to KGTV, Crocker is the son of Matthew Hedge, a convicted sex offender who made headlines not only for his child molestation convictions, but also a judge's controversial decision to lift Hedge's sexually violent predator status and release him from custody without supervision. KGTV cites statements from the alleged victim's mother regarding Crocker's parentage, though the District Attorney's office has not confirmed the relation. Crocker, who faces 18 years in prison if convicted of all charges, was arrested Wednesday and remains in custody on $1 million bail, according to county jail records. He's next due in court Aug. 16. Hedge pleaded guilty in 1989 to molesting four children in the San Diego area and served 12 years in prison. He was committed to the sexually violent predator treatment program in 1997, but was released into outpatient treatment in 2005 in a trailer outside Donovan State Prison in Otay Mesa. His outpatient status was revoked within six weeks for violating terms of his release. After more than two years of in-patient hospital treatment, the court in October 2008 again granted Hedge's petition to be placed in outpatient treatment. In 2012, he was released without supervision after San Diego Superior Court Judge David Gill determined he no longer posed a danger to others and was unlikely to re-offend. – City News Service

A man was arrested for allegedly attacking a homeless man in what police are investigating as a suspected hate crime in Georgetown.  Richard Walter Moore, 40, was arrested on an assault charge for the incident that occurred on the corner of Wisconsin Avenue and M Street at about 1 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 2.  Moore, a white man, allegedly attacked the black victim who was panhandling on the corner. Police said Moore called the victim racial slurs and told him to leave the corner he was sitting at.  The victim walked away from the corner and Moore followed him to an alley in the 1000 block of Wisconsin Ave, NW, police said. Moore then allegedly punched and kicked the man, and picked up a metal railing plant holder and struck him, police said. The victim was treated at the scene for non-life threatening injuries.  Police said they are investigating this incident as a hate or bias crime.  "The designation can be changed at any point as an investigation proceeds and more information is gathered. A designation as a hate crime by MPD does not mean that prosecutors will prosecute it as a hate crime," police said in a statement.  Moore, of no fixed address, was charged with Assault with a Dangerous Weapon. Patch File Photo

Written by Lisa Baumann and Jeanne Gustafson. At a King County District Court on Tuesday, Aug. 20, bail was set at $250,000 for a former Shoreline Police Officer of the year who is accused of theft, evidence tampering, and possession of stolen property. Mitch Wright, 33 years old and a 10-year veteran of the King County Sheriff's Office, was arrested Monday morning, Aug. 19, on multiple charges at his Bothell area home, according to Cindi West of the King County Sheriff's Office. In 2006, Wright was named Shoreline Police Officer of the year, and according to the department's annual report, during that year he made more than 150 arrests, including numerous arrests of suspects in stolen cars, felony narcotics violations, and other serious crimes.  Wright was booked into the King County Jail on several charges, including: Investigation of Theft, Possession of Stolen Property, Tampering, and Possession of a Controlled Substance.  According to a report in the Seattle Times,  Wright is accused of failing to turn any of the drugs he was responsible for logging in during the course of an undercover operation with the Drug Enforcement Administration. Monday's arrest came out of an unrelated internal investigation conducted by the Sheriff's Office into allegations the deputy was using government computer systems to access information contrary to policy.  Wright resigned in lieu of termination on July 9, 2013.

An assistant water polo and swimming coach at Kennedy High School in La Palma faces allegations of sexually assaulting 14- to 16- year-old girls, Buena Park police reported Tuesday. Joshua Christopher Owens, 23, of La Palma, was arrested Monday on suspicion of molesting an unspecified number of victims, according to Buena Park Police Department Sgt. Mike Lovchik. Owens was released from the city's jail after posting $75,000 bail, Lovchik said. Owens coached at Kennedy High School in the 2014-15 and 2015-16 school years, Lovchik said. He is accused of molesting the victims during those school years, according to Lovchik. Owens worked as a seasonal lifeguard with the Long Beach Fire Department's Marine Safety Division this year, Lovchik said. Investigators suspect there may be more victims and asked anyone with relevant information to call Detective Todd Franssen at (714) 562-3963. --  City news Service, photo courtesy of Buena Park Police Department.

A Crofton woman was stabbed and beaten to death Sunday, medical authorities say, while her boyfriend remains in jail without bond on murder and other charges in her death. Ryan Gregory Hollebon, 38, of the 1700 block of Carry Place in Crofton, is accused of violently attacking  Jhalandia Elaine Butler , 28, of the same address, Sunday night. Butler was pronounced dead at the scene. Anne Arundel County Police received a call about domestic violence about 9:24 p.m. Sunday, March 5, at the house in the 1700 block of Carry Place in Crofton. Officers arrived at the scene to find Butler lying inside the residence, while Hollebon had fled. He was taken into custody Monday in the 1300 block of East Patapsco Avenue in Baltimore City, police said. Multiple Anne Arundel County residents alerted police with tips and possible sightings of Hollebon that were followed up on, authorities said. An arrest warrant charged Hollebon with first-degree murder, second-degree murder, first-degree assault, second-degree assault and deadly weapon with intent to injure in Butler's death. On Monday, the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner performed an autopsy on Butler and ruled the cause of death was multiple sharped-edge wounds coupled with blunt force trauma and the manner was homicide. Even though an arrest has been made in the case, investigators ask anyone with information on Butler's murder to call the Homicide Unit at 410-222-4731. Anonymous tips can be made to the Anne Arundel County Police Tip Line 410-222-4700 or Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866- 7LOCKUP or text "MCS plus your message" to CRIMES (274637). »Photo of murder suspect Ryan Hollebon of Crofton, courtesy of the Anne Arundel County Police Department

Crime Stoppers is offering a reward up to $5,000 if anyone can come forward with information that leads to the arrest of two men suspected of sex crimes against minors. Ellis Burns, 21, of the 1900 block of Lilac Lane in Aurora, has a warrant out for his arrest with bail set at $5 million. He's charged with the following: Crime Stoppers can be reached at 630-892-1000. All callers remain anonymous.  Aurora police said an acquaintance of Burns, Dametrius D. Thornton, 23, of the 100 block of Fox Chase Drive in Oswego, is currently being held in the Kane County Jail in lieu of a $750,000 bail. He has been charged with the following: Thornton's charges stem from alleged crimes against two, 15-year-old girls, who were also victimized by Burns, according to Aurora police. Officials believe there are more victims, and would like to hear from them by calling the investigations division at 630-256-5500. Additional charges against them haven't been ruled out, officials said. Thornton's next court date is Jan. 31. He and Burns are presumed innocent unless proven guilty in the court of law beyond a reasonable doubt. Photos: Aurora Police

A 74-year-old Springfield man was arrested Saturday on 33 counts of theft, forgery and possession of a forged instrument. His alleged crime? Stealing cold sore medicine and returning it for cash at Bi-Mart stores. His take? Roughly $4,281.  Oregon State Police say they began investigating Terrence Lee Liddell in July after a trooper pulled him over for an unspecified traffic violation and found evidence of apparent shoplifting.  Over a two-month investigation, during which detectives obtained surveillance video and warrants to search Liddell's personal computer, Oregon State Police reportedly discovered evidence Liddell had been stealing Abreva cold sore medication and returning it to Bi-Marts in Oregon and Washington. When investigators interviewed him Sept. 23, Liddell reportedly admitted to the accusations and showed police the printer and stolen Bi-Mart printer paper he used to make the forged return receipts. Liddell was lodged at the Lane County Jail but has since been released. Image via Shutterstock

A 40-year-old homeless man has been accused of sexually assaulting a homeless woman in southwest Miami-Dade and attempting to sexually assault another. Police fear there may be other victims. Lyndon Merlick Nicaisse was charged with sexual battery and attempted sexual battery stemming from the two incidents that occurred between 2:30 a.m. and 5 a.m. on July 27 and July 28. "Nicaisse is homeless and known to frequent the area of the South Miami-Dade Busway and Southwest 160th Street," according to Detective Argemis Colome of the Miami-Dade Police Department, who said that police are asking other possible victims to come forward. Colome said that both victims were sleeping when Nicaisse allegedly assaulted one of them and attempted to assault the other.  One of the victims told police that she awoke to find Nicaisse straddling her body with his penis exposed. He allegedly attempted to pull her pants down, and allegedly told her that he was going to have sex with her. The victim struck her attacker and he ran away, according to police. The other woman was sleeping in a parking lot near the busway when Nicaisse allegedly laid down beside her, pulled her pants down and allegedly sexually assaulted her. "The victim was able to push Nicaisse and ran to a nearby restaurant to call police," Colome said. "Uniform officers responded to the scene and located Nicaisse, where he was positively identified by the victim and arrested." The case was investigated by the Miami-Dade Police Department Special Victims Bureau. To report a tip, call Miami-Dade Crime Stoppers at 305-471-8477 or 866-471-8477; visit  www.crimestoppersmiami.com  and select "Give a Tip" or text "CSMD" followed by the tip to 274637.  Photo courtesy Miami-Dade Police Department

The man accused of gunning down a man in Haverford Township this summer, appeared in court Thursday and will now head to a trial to face numerous charges related to the seemingly senseless killing. Derrick Hershal Rollins, 24, of Philadelphia, had all charges filed against him in connection with 29-year-old John Le's July slaying held over for trial at his preliminary hearing on Thursday, Oct. 26, court records show. Rollins will go on to face charges of criminal homicide; first, second, and third degree murder; aggravated assault; prohibited possession of a firearm; robbery; and more in connection with the killing that stunned the quiet Main Line community. His formal arraignment is set for Nov. 9 in a Delaware County court and he remains behind bars as he was not granted bail. The fatal shooting occurred at about 6 p.m. Saturday, July 28 at an apartment on the 2300 block of Haverford Road in the Ardmore section of the township. Le, of Narberth, was reportedly walking to a friend's home with a pizza when he was shot. About 45 minutes before Le's death, Rollins also allegedly fired numerous rounds at two men in Philadelphia's Overbrook neighborhood who said they confronted Rollins as he was peering into a neighbors' home. According to Main Line Media News, a  Haverford Township Police Detective and one of the men Rollins allegedly shot at in Overbrook spoke as witnesses at Thursday's hearing. Rollins,  who was taken into custody in Dekalb County, Georgia in late August  after multiple law enforcement agencies including U.S. Marshals issued an alert for his arrest, allegedly told the detective that the media made him a "monster" and that he ran from the shooting scene like everyone else did.   Image via Haverford Township Police

A Williamstown man was arrested for stealing copper wiring from a business on Jarvis Road over the weekend, Gloucester Township police said on Thursday. Derrick J. Niblick, 32, is accused of stealing the wiring from the business at about 6:14 a.m. on Saturday morning, Nov. 2, police said.  Police said they used video surveillance to get a description of the thief and the car he was driving. Police then used an automated license plate reader to identify Niblick as the suspect. Police arrested Niblick after stopping him during an enhanced patrol in the area of Sicklerville Road and Stonebridge Drive at about 10:53 p.m. Wednesday night. Niblick was taken to police headquarters, where he was charged with theft and released on a criminal summons, police said.

A man accused of breaking into and vandalizing North Mesquite High School was arrested Wednesday after briefly fleeing from police. Joseph James Morris, 24, was arrested after a tipster reported him to police around 6:15 p.m. in the 1900 block of South Parkway in Mesquite. Police said the man fled when officers arrived but was arrested one block away after a brief chase. Morris, of Odessa, had been staying in Mesquite for the past week, police said. He is held on charges of evading arrest, burglary of a building, burglary of a coin operated machine and criminal mischief of an amount between $750 and $30,000. ( Subscribe to your local Texas Patch  for daily newsletters and breaking news updates.) Police allege Morris  entered the school around midnight Monday  and vandalized the office, hallways and cafeteria, broke into a vending machine and piled electronics and other items near two exit doors, police say. Investigators believe the man intended to steal the items he had piled by the doors. He fled around 5:30 am. when he opened an exterior door and triggered an alarm. Image via Mesquite Police Department

A township man was arrested for allegedly stalking and threatening juveniles for years, including following them to school events, police said Thursday. Yossef Eshak, 19, was arrested and charged after police investigated a car being "keyed" near Worcester Drive Oct. 6, said Detective Capt. Laurence Martin. The car had several deep scrapes in the shape of an "X" on it, Martin said.  Police spoke with the victim and Eshak was identified as a suspect, who police said allegedly stalked the victim and his friends "for several years," the captain said. Detective Sgt. Scott Rappaport investigated and spoke with a girl's family who provided police with two years of threatening and intimidating text messages; Eshak also allegedly followed the victims to school functions, Martin said. Eshak was warned to stop the behavior, but "continued causing emotional distress" and physically threatened the victims' family and friends using cell phones and on social media, Martin said Eshak was charged with criminal coercion, criminal mischief, endangering and abuse of minors, cyber harassment, stalking and making terroristic threats, police said. Anyone with information regarding this case or other related cases should call Rappaport at 973-633-3528. Email  daniel.hubbard@patch.com . Get Patch breaking news alerts sent right to your phone with our new app.  Download here . Photo: Youssef Eshak, 19/Wayne Police Department

Tewksbury police arrested a 38-year-old Methuen man on drug charges after police witnessed an alleged drug transaction in the parking lot of a Tewksbury hotel on Thursday, according to police.  Durrell Alexander, 38 of 75 Union St., Apt.6, Methuen was charged with distribution of a class b substance, cocaine, possession with the intent to distribute a class b substance, cocaine and operating a motor vehicle with a revoked license, police said.  Detectives observed Alexander conducting a drug transaction in the parking lot of the Extended Stay America Hotel. Alexander was subsequently arrested and cocaine was recovered. Additional cocaine was located and seized from Alexander's room when Detectives executed a search warrant. The Tewksbury Police Department urges any citizens who suspect criminal activity to call the Dispatch Center @ 978-851-7373. If you wish to remain anonymous please call the Tip Line @ 978-851-0175 or send an email to  tewks_detectives@tewksbury-ma.gov   Courtesy photo from Tewksbury Police Department.

If any of the above suspects look familiar, contact the Placer County Sheriff's Office. Investigators believe they are linked to a residential burglary that took place July 16 in Roseville.  Four suspects allegedly broke into a home on Whyte Avenue in Roseville and stole multiple items, including an ATM card. They attempted to use the card at an ATM in Carmichael. The photos above are from the attempted transaction.  Investigators are searching for one female and three male suspects. Anyone with information could be eligible for a cash reward of up to $1,000 if the information leads to an arrest.  Anyone who may know their identities is urged to call Det. Chris Glaspell at 916-652-2445. Anyone wishing to remain anonymous and be eligible for a cash reward is asked to call Placer County Crime Stoppers at 1-800-923-8191.

A Perris man is behind bars Tuesday, accused of a bizarre series of events that included breaking into a Lake Elsinore business to burglarize the place and then lighting fires inside.  Riverside County officials say that they were called to the 2400 Block of East Lakeshore Avenue around 8 a.m. Monday for a "commercial burglary occurring at a business."  "Officers arrived and found the business was forcibly broken into and located a suspect inside," police said in a news release. "The suspect was hiding in the attic of the building and was starting fires."  Police officers said they tried to arrest the man, identified as 46-year-old Jodie Meza. However, he "refused and attempted to hang himself."  Law enforcement rushed to rescue Meza, took him out of the attic and firefighters doused the blaze, sheriff's officials said. Then, while he was being detained, Meza allegedly attacked an officer.  Meza was treated at an area hospital and then taken to the Cois Byrd Detention Center in French Valley, the sheriff's department said. He was booked on suspicion of commercial burglary, arson, and resisting a peace officer, records show. His bail was set at $55,000.  Anyone with information related to the incident was asked to call Officer Foster at Riverside County Sheriff's dispatch at (951) 776-1099, or the Lake Elsinore Police Department at (951) 245-3300.  — Patch file photo by Renee Schiavone

Police said a Groton man has been arrested and charged in a Waterford home invasion  in which he allegedly assaulted his ex-girlfriend , the New London Day reported. The incident occurred Friday at an unidentified Quaker Hill residence, according to police. Police said George F. Bassett, 52, of Groton is  charged with showing up at his ex-girlfriend's home  and going on a rampage after accusing the victim of seeing other men, according to the new London Day. He then allegedly strangled and punched the woman multiple times. The suspect also allegedly put holes in the wall of the home, knocked over vases and  ripped a refrigerator door off its hinges , the New London Day reported. Waterford police said the victim's injuries lined up with her story and asked Groton City police to locate and arrest the suspect, which they did. Read the full story at the New London Day. Image via Shutterstock

Deonte Taylor, a Walnut Grove Elementary School teacher, has been charged with three counts of first-degree statutory sodomy for a sexual assault that prosecutors say happened when he was a teacher's assistant at Lusher Elementary School in the nearby Hazelwood School District. Authorities say the assault happened in November 2015. Taylor is accused of pulling a 7-year-old student out of class and sodomizing him in an empty room. Prosecutors say they have DNA evidence linking Taylor to the assault.   The boy reported the assault in 2015, but police didn't arrest Taylor until Thursday, more than three years later. The Post-Dispatch reports  Taylor was placed on leave and subsequently fired for unrelated reasons  after the allegations came to light in Hazelwood, but parents weren't notified and Taylor was later rehired in by the Ferguson-Florissant School District. "The district would not knowingly hire a potential employee who had a record of or had committed crimes against children," the district wrote in a prepared statement. The district says it conducted a background check and that Taylor had no criminal history, but it's not clear how the allegation — which was included in his file from Hazelwood, according to a Hazelwood district spokesperson — slipped by in the hiring process. A warrant was issued for Taylor on Wednesday and he was taken into custody on Thursday. He is held on $250,000 cash-only bond. No attorney is listed. Image via Shutterstock

Detectives in Orange County arrested three people suspected of pulling off a scheme to steal jewelry from real estate open houses across the county, including homes in San Clemente, Anaheim and Ladera Ranch. The trio, a man and two women, allegedly nabbed more than $20,000 in jewelry from unsuspecting home owners. Authorities were able to get back thousands of dollars worth of stolen items. Detectives also found a ledger complete with the details of scheduled open houses in Orange, San Diego and Los Angeles counties, said Jaimee Blashaw of the sheriff's department. All three suspects are residents of Los Angeles. Nino Siganoff, 33, Valerie Siganoff, 36, and Barbara Adams, 29, were arrested Tuesday on suspicion of felony burglary. "Investigators believe the suspects started running the scheme in October," said Jaimee Blashaw of the sheriff's department. "A male suspect would distract the real estate agent, while two female suspects would search other areas of the home and steal items." Investigators believe the $20,000 worth of items recovered are from homes in Ladera Ranch, San Clemente and Anaheim, Blashaw said.  "While a portion of the recovered property has been returned to some of the victims, the property reunification process is ongoing," Blashaw said. "Sheriff's investigators also believe there are potentially more victims of this scheme." Authorities released photos of recovered items, and urged possible victims to call investigators at (949) 206-6100. Anyone with additional information who would like to submit an anonymous tip can contact Crime Stoppers at (855_ TIP-OCCS, or via the website www.occrimestoppers.org. City News Service contributed to this report. Photos courtesy of the Orange County Sheriff's Department.

Police said a 19-year-old New London man was arrested Friday for allegedly driving a dirt bike recklessly around city streets. The accused's charges includes the new city ordinance targeting illegal dirt bikes, which carries a $1,000 fine, police said. According to a news release, police said Elishsha Vessells, 19, was wanted on criminal charges stemming from an illegal dirt bike riding incident that occurred on Aug. 15. Police said the accused was observed recklessly driving a dirt bike along various city streets throughout New London and failed to obey police orders to stop. Police said the accused was arrested on charges of reckless driving, interfering with police, operating under suspension, failure to insure motorcycle, operating unregistered motor vehicle and failure to obey officer's signal. According to police, the accused was also found in possession of four grams of marijuana and subsequently charged with possession of less than half an ounce of marijuana. Anyone who has information concerning criminal activity is encouraged to contact the New London Police Department at 860-447-5269 (ext. 0). Anonymous information may be submitted via the New London Tips 411 system by texting NLPDTip plus the information to Tip411 (847411). To sign up for New London breaking news alerts and more, click here. Photo credit: New London Police Department  Facebook page

The man accused of robbing the TD Bank in Peabody back in November was arrested Monday. Jason S. Englen, 34, of Chelsea is charged with the Peabody robbery; as well as robberies in Arlington, Reading and Burlingon. According to the U.S. Attorney's office, a suspect identified as Englen first entered the TD Bank in Arlington on Oct. 31, approached a teller and presented a note with the word "Robery" written on it. The teller handed him money from the drawer and he fled the bank. The U.S. Attorney's office indicates that nearly identical incidents occurred in Reading, Burlington and Peabody. During each of the incidents, the man handed the teller a note with the word "Robery" or "Robert" demanding cash. He allegedly  robbed the TD Bank at 79 Lynnfield St. in November . The FBI dubbed the suspect the "Spelling Bee Bandit" due to the misspelled notes that were passed to tellers. After each of the alleged incidents, surveillance pictures were circulated across the state. Authorities were able to identify Englen as the suspect of the robberies, and learned that Englen was already in state custody on unrelated charges. If convicted, Englen could face a sentence of up to 20 years and prison, three years supervised lease, and a fine of $250,000. Image via the FBI Story by Joe Lipovich

Gwinnett Police have released a sketch drawing of the possible suspect in a recent sexual assault last week, during which he allegedly carjacked a woman and forced her at gunpoint to go with him. The sketch, with the assistance of the victim, depicts the man wanted in the  July 30 attack near Lawrenceville Highway  in unincorporated Lawrenceville. His description: The victim told officers she was driving home after getting off from work around 8:30 p.m. last Thursday, and was stopped at a red light on Lawrenceville Highway north of Pleasant Hill Road. She said once the light turned green, she was rear-ended by another vehicle. She told police she got out of her car to see what happened, but the man pulled out a handgun and ordered her back inside. She further told police the two continued down Lawrenceville Highway and turned right onto an unknown road, where the man allegedly assaulted her inside the vehicle. The suspect's car was seized by police. Gwinnett Police public information officer Cpl. Michele Pihera said Crime Scene Unit investigators were able to find physical evidence in the vehicle. That evidence is being processed by the GBI. If you have info on this case, contact GCPD detectives at  770-513-5371  or  770-513-5300 . To remain anonymous, tipsters should contact Crime Stoppers at 404 577-TIPS (8477) or visit  www.crimestoppersatlanta.org . Crime Stoppers tipsters can receive up to $2,000 for information leading to an arrest and indictment in this case. Sketch from Gwinnett Police

A Bayside man is accused of stealing more than $35,000 from a Long Island church while serving as the church's treasurer. Ronald Ousman, 38, surrendered Tuesday morning to DA investigators and was arraigned on a third degree grand larceny charge, Acting Nassau County District Attorney Madeline Singas said. Ousman allegedly stole $35,608 from Holy Trinity Orthodox Church, located at 369 Green Avenue in East Meadow, from May 16, 2014 until May 7, 2015. Ousman made a series of cash withdrawals from the church's checking and money market accounts, Singas said. The investigation began when church officials contacted the Internal Revenue Service to verify certain tax information, Singas said. IRS employees informed church officials that certain payments were never received by the IRS and an investigation was opened by the DA's office in May. "The defendant was a trusted member of the faith community, but is charged with taking advantage of that trust by stealing more than $35,000 from a house of worship," Singas said. "I thank church officials for bringing this alleged theft to our attention and encourage members of the public to reach out to my office if they suspect a crime has taken place." Ousman faces up to seven years in prison if convicted. He was was released on his own recognizance Tuesday and is due back in court on Sept. 15.

6-11-12 Police reported a vehicle break-in in the 12000 block of Meadow Green Place. The driver side window had been smashed, but nothing appeared to have been taken.  6-12-12 Temple Emanuel reported money and credit cards had been stolen. The number of cards and the amount of money was not disclosed. Detectives arrested a suspect in connection with an alleged jewelry theft on Chatfield Place Road reported June 6. The jewelry owner reported the items were missing after a Memorial Day party. The suspect was turned over to Ladue police on suspicion of similar crimes. 6-14-12 Police took a report of Identity theft report from a construction firm located at #2 City Place. The company claims its credit card had been skimmed and used in New Orleans. Officers responded to 450 N New Ballas for a report of a subject looking into cars and car alarms going off. A resident in the 900 block of Spoede Road reported that her paymelater.com had been compromised and that someone used it to make purchases worth $1,654. 6-16-12 . The victim was taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The truck drove off. The investigation continues. 6-17-12 Two TVs were reported stolen from the. Police say suspects worked together, with one distracting a store employee while the other stole the TVs. Suspects fled the area. Police are not describing the vehicle.

An 18-year-old man accused of of raping a clerk at an El Monte convenience store was expected to be arraigned tomorrow at Pomona Superior Court. Joseph Leo Amaya is charged with two counts of forcible rape and three counts of sexual penetration by a foreign object. The charges include an allegation that he kidnapped the victim, a 19-year-old college student, to commit those crimes. Amaya allegedly approached the victim as she was working the night shift at the Peck Mini Mart at 4164 N. Peck Road. He left the store, but allegedly returned when the clerk was getting ready to close up. As she tried to lock the doors, Amaya forced his way back in, barricaded the entrance and dragged the young woman to the back of the store, where he repeatedly sexually assaulted her, prosecutors allege. Public tips and investigation by the U.S. Marshal's Pacific Southwest Regional Fugitive Task Force and county Sheriff's and Probation departments led to Amaya's arrest in West Covina on Saturday. Police say he is a gang member with the initials of his gang tatooed on his right arm. Amaya was jailed in lieu of $5 million bail. If convicted as charged, he faces a maximum sentence of 125 years to life in state prison. -- City News Service

A Milton man was arrested Friday and charged with federal sex trafficking crimes, the U.S. Attorney's office said. Duhamel Cassagnol, 30, is accused of recruiting and transporting women across state lines to engage in sex acts, knowing that they would be subject to force, fraud or coercion, according to authorities. He also allegedly took women between states to participate in prostitution.  Cassagnol was charged in an indictment with committing sex trafficking by force, fraud or coercion; engaging in a conspiracy to commit sex trafficking; and transporting an individual for prostitution. His alleged crimes took place between July 2014 and February 2016, the USAO said.  A Connecticut woman, 23-year-old Geneiva Whaley, was charged in a criminal complaint with transporting an individual for prostitution. Authorities said Whaley knowingly took one of Cassagnol's victims from Massachusetts to Connecticut in October of 2015 for the purpose of prostitution.  Whaley allegedly recruited the woman, who had just been released from a detox facility, and worked with Cassagnol to keep her in various hotels in Connecticut. The pair allegedly gave the woman drugs and prostituted her while she stayed at the hotels, which were in Whaley's name, the USAO said.  Cassagnol and Whaley were detained following an appearance in federal court Friday afternoon.  Image via Shutterstock

Redlands Unified School District officials released a statement Thursday about the arrest a day earlier of a Clement Middle School teacher on suspicion of possessing a controlled substance and paraphernalia. Jennifer Tena Krogman, 40, was arrested Wednesday at her home in Beaumont. She was cited by Redlands police and released early Thursday. She could not be reached to comment for this report. Here is the Redlands Unified School District statement, shared with Redlands-Loma Linda Patch by Assistant Superintendent Brad Mason: "The district has been informed that Jennifer Krogman was arrested on drug related allegations. It is the district's policy once those allegations have been confirmed, to place the employee on paid administrative leave upon return to duty from summer break. This continues until the resolution of the criminal charges and the district's internal investigation." The East Valley Street Enforcement Team, comprised of Redlands police and San Bernardino County deputies, arrested Krogman at her home in the 1600 block of Apollo Way in Beaumont around 3 p.m. July 31, Redlands police Lt. Travis Martinez said Thursday evening in a phone interview. Krogman was allegedly packaging a small amount of methamphetamine to be mailed out of state, Martinez said. For a previous Patch report on Krogman's arrest click here: Redlands Teacher Accused of Possessing Controlled Substance, Paraphernalia

Sheriff's deputies in Thousand Oaks Thursday identified two people suspected in a series of thefts involving wallets taken from shopping carts over the past five months. Darryl Kilgore, of Los Angeles, 51 and Pillar Abalos, 42, of Poway, have apparently been going into Thousand Oaks to do their alleged stealing since November, according to authorities. Women placing their purses in the child seats of the shopping carts were targeted. According to law enforcement officials, the suspects waited for the shoppers to become distracted and would quicly snatch wallets from the purses; another suspect would use the stolen cards to withdraw cash advances from banks, police said. The cards were also used to buy electronics from local retail stores, officials said. Abalos was arrested at the San Fernando Courthouse March 27; Kilgore was collared Wednesday in Los Angeles, deputies said. Abalos was booked on suspicion of identity theft, misuse of an access card, burglary and conspiracy to commit a crime. Kilgore was booked for alleged burglary and conspiracy to commit a crime. Three other suspects -- were still being sought, law enforcement authorities said. One of the outstanding suspects is a young woman, between 18 and 25; another is between 30 and 35 and the third is about 40, according to sheriff's officials. Law enforcement authorities caution residents to be aware of their valuables when shopping, as thieves need only a few seconds of distraction to steal. They offer the following tips on keeping your purses safe:

Updated 12:42 p.m. Jan 11 : A 20-year old Spring man accused of killing another man durng an arguent over tennis shoes was arrested in La Porte on Tuesday.  Ja'Corrie Rogers was arrested at about 4:30 Tuesday and is being held in the Jefferson County jail on a $50,000 bond. Witnesses said Rogers shot Darius Flournoy to death while Flournoy was playing basketball with friends in the 2400 block of Autumn Springs Lane on Monday night. Witnesses said they initially thought the altercation was a joke, and that the gun was a toy, but when Flournoy away from Rogers and started laughing, Rogers allegedly shot him multiple times and drove away. Investigators have not said when Rogers could be transfered to Harris County, Original Story : SPRING, TX -- A 20-year old Spring man is wanted for allegedly shooting and killing another man during a game of pickup basketball Monday evening. Police said the victim, identified as Darius Flournoy, 21, was playing basketball with friends in the 2400 block of Autumn Springs Lane at about 7 p.m., when a car pulled up and a man got out. The driver of the car, identified as Ja'Corrie Rogers, 20, began arguing with Flournoy about a pair of tennis shoes, according to police. Witnesses told police that Rogers pulled out a gun and fired several shots before getting into his car and driving away. Flournoy was shot several times and died a short time later at Houston Northwest Medical Center. Rogers is charged with murder and is considered armed and dangerous, police said. Anyone with information about Rogers's whereabouts is asked to call the Harris County Sheriff's Office Homicide Unit at 713-274-9100 or Crime Stoppers at 713-222-TIPS. Image: Shutterstock

Police in Marietta said more arrests could come from an extensive two-year investigation into an alleged gambling enterprise that netted three arrests this week. Law enforcement officials raided the Gantt grocery on Franklyn Gateway in Marietta, confiscating $250,000 in cash, eight computers, a cellphone, five luxury cars and a tote full of gold jewelry.  Investigators said that more search warrants are forthcoming as law enforcement officers concentrate on the impounded property and bank accounts linked to the suspects. Read more :  Cash, jewelry seized in gambling raid in Marietta Law enforcement authorities have focused their activities on the Gantt store at 1033 Franklin Gateway suite No. 22 and a convenience store on Windy Hill Parkway, both owned by Khubab M. Hussain. His Douglasville home was also searched by authorities.  Also arrested were Sampson Tabor Beye, a Gantt employee, and Arif Muhammad, an employee of the store on Windy Hill Road. All three are charged with with felony commercial gambling. Police believe they've uncovered a large criminal scheme involving organized gambling and possible money laundering. Images via Marietta PD

A 25-year-old Bronx, NY woman was arrested on charges of forgery and identity theft after she allegedly tried to cash a fraudulent check for $4,532 at TD Banks in Darien, Greenwich and Stamford, according to Darien police. Kashai Princess George was charged with criminal impersonation, first-degree forgery and third-degree identity theft when she was apprehended on March 3 at the TD Bank on the Post Road in Darien. Officers were dispatched to the bank following a report of a woman trying to cash a fraudulent check, who turned out to be the same woman who tried to cash checks in the other mentioned towns. To cash the checks, George allegedly had used a NY driver's license bearing the name "Sarojni Basil." "When asked if the information she had given to the bank was hers, George admitted that it was not. She stated that the driver's license had someone else's information with her (George's) picture," wrote Darien police in a statement. "Based on the above, George was placed under arrest. "In speaking with bank employees, they informed officers that they had been sent an internal notice about the suspect as she had gone to branches in Greenwich and Stamford attempting to get account information and cash checks under the name Sarojni Basil." A teller at the Darien branch had immediately recognized the name George was using and notified a co-worker. The two were then able to stall George until police arrived. While searching George, police found the check written out to Sarojni Basil in the amount of $4,532. Bail for George was set at $10,000, and she was scheduled to appear in Stamford Superior Court on March 5. Image via Shutterstock

Police have arrested a 22-year-old D.C. man who is accused of robbing multiple taxicab drivers with a knife in Northeast and Southeast Washington.  Thomas Maynard Parker, of Northeast, was arrested and charged with three counts of armed robbery Wednesday, police said.  According to police, Parker robbed three taxi drivers from December 2016 to September 2017. The most recent incident happened September 2, 2017 in the 3500 block of A Street SE.  Police say the taxi driver drove Parker to the above location at about 4:15 p.m. When they arrived at the drop off location, Parker then brandished a knife and demanded the driver to hand over his property, police said. The victim complied and the suspect fled on foot. Like us on Facebook to follow all crime news: Patch File Photo

Authorities have arrested a man who allegedly was part of a group that assaulted an off-duty Newark police officer on Tuesday. According to the Newark Department of Public Safety, the officer got into a collision with another driver around 11:05 p.m. near Bloomfield and Mount Prospect Avenues. When he saw someone on the ground, the officer got out of his vehicle. At that point, a group of men allegedly assaulted him and took his cell phone, even though he repeatedly told them that he was a police officer. The driver of the other car managed to run to safety during the assault, police said. After the assault, the injured officer's on-duty peers arrived on the scene to lend aid. Emergency responders transported him to University Hospital for treatment, authorities said. After conducting an investigation, Newark detectives identified Geraldo Concepcion, 27, of Newark, one of the suspects who allegedly attacked and robbed the officer. Police arrested Concepcion on Wednesday and charged him with aggravated assault and conspiracy. (See below photo) "Several other suspects remain at large as this investigation continues," the Newark Department of Public Safety stated Wednesday. "While police are actively searching for other suspects, we seek the public's assistance in quickly locating and removing them from our streets." Anyone with information can call the department's 24-hour Crime Stopper tip line at 1-877-NWK-TIPS (1-877-695-8477) or 1-877-NWK-GUNS (1-877-695-4867). Anonymous tips may also be made using the Police Division's website at:  www.newarkpd.org  or through its Smartphone App available at iTunes or on Google Play. Keep updated with local public safety alerts at the Patch Newark Facebook page.   Send local news tips and correction requests to eric.kiefer@patch.com Photo of Geraldo Concepcion: Newark Department of Public Safety Main photo: Shutterstock

A Pennsylvania man stands accused of attempting to engage in a sexual relationship with a 15-year-old girl in Somers Point, the Atlantic County Prosecutor's Office said on Wednesday. Dean Leon, 48, of Enola, Pa., is charged with enticement of a 15-year-old girl, aggravated criminal sexual contact and possession of child pornography. He was arrested in his car by Somers Point Police on March 31. Police allege Leon set up a meeting with the girl online.  Under the recent Criminal Justice Reform rules, the court may order Leon to be detained without bail or released with conditions. However, his pretrial detention hearing, originally scheduled for Wednesday, was postponed until Thursday afternoon,  The Press of Atlantic City  reports. The hearing was postponed when Superior Court Judge Michael Blee found that Leon, who receives unemployment and disability benefits, can't afford an attorney. He will be assigned a public defender.

Police have arrested a West Orange man wanted along with another suspect in last month's armed robbery of a Chatham Borough jewelry store, a report says. According to the Morris County Prosecutor's Office, Michael Reed, 46, of Newark, and Raiys Grimes, 35, of West Orange, were charged with Robbery and Conspiracy to Commit Robbery, Possession of a Weapon for Unlawful Purpose, Unlawful Possession of a Weapon, Theft, Conspiracy to Commit Theft, Burglary, Conspiracy to Commit Burglary, Criminal Restraint, Conspiracy to Commit Criminal Restraint and Aggravated Assault (pointing a firearm). Grimes  turned himself in to police on Friday , TAP Into Millburn/Short Hills reported. Police arrested Reed last week at his mother's home in Newark. Authorities allege that around 11 a.m. on July 28, Reed and Grimes allegedly entered Crescent Jewelers at 251 Main Street in Chatham and stole jewelry and cash valued in excess of $75,000. During the robbery, a handgun was produced and  a store employee was physically restrained , prosecutors said. Police previously said that the two suspects then made their getaway in a silver or gray Jeep driven by a third male, who was described as a bald, black male with a beard.  During the course of a subsequent investigation, law enforcement officers recovered various proceeds from the robbery, as well as the handgun that is alleged to have been used during the crime, prosecutors said.

An 18-year-old man and a juvenile girl were arrested Monday evening after allegedly carjacking a vehicle they pretended to be interested in purchasing, according to a report. Darius Polk, 18, and the girl are being accused of stealing the vehicle from the 300 block of St. Charles Street. Police received a call around 5:45 p.m. from a man who lived there, reporting the incident. He told investigators his vehicle was for sale and the two suspects were interested, the Chicago Sun Times reported. While they test drove the car, the girl pulled out a knife, threatening the victim and ordering him to get out of the vehicle, according to the Sun Times, and Polk told him to give up his property. Police then  found the vehicle  and the girl in the 200 block of Michigan Street. Officers set up a perimeter and got a K-9 unit to the scene. They found Polk in the first block of Center Street, the Sun Times reported. Each are being charged with aggravated vehicular hijacking and armed robbery. Polk, of Chicago's Southwest Side, is being held on $1 million bond and the girl was taken to Kane County Youth Home. Article image Kane County Sheriff's Office

A Centereach woman who was employed as a nurse at  Medford Multicare Center for Living  is accused of falsifying medical records and taking painkillers from the nursing home for her own personal use.  Attorney General Eric Schneiderman announced the arrest of 32-year-old Nicholle Gavegli on Wednesday.  Authorities say Gavegli claimed to have administered multiple prescribed Percocet tablets to a nursing home resident from Medford when she did not actually do so. Gavegli instead kept the pills for her own unauthorized use, Schneiderman said.  "All nursing home employees have a solemn responsibility to properly care for their patients, including ensuring that they receive prescribed medications," Schneiderman said. "The falsification of medical records and theft of drugs – especially dangerous and addictive prescription narcotics – will not be tolerated by my office." Gaveglia has been a licensed practical nurse since 2005. According to the Attorney General's felony complaint, from June 9 - July 27, 2014, while working as a medication nurse and caring for residents at the nursing home located at 3115 Horseblock Road, Gaveglia allegedly falsely recorded in a resident's medical records that she administered the Percocet tablets.  Gaveglia allegedly later admitted to falsifying the records to cover up her theft and illegal possession of the drugs. She is charged with first degree falsifying business records, seventh degree criminal possession of a controlled substance and petty larceny.  Gaveglia was arraigned before before Judge Pierce Cohalon in First District Court in Central Islip on Wednesday. The case was adjourned for a conference on July 15 in the same court. Photo: Google Maps More on Patch:

Those looking for a slightly more risque ending to their massage experience in Stamford this week risked running into police. The SPD conducted a raid on four suspect locations and issued charges ranging from prostitution to practicing massage therapy without a license. *** Two burglars suspects allegedly caught stealing tools from someone's garage early Thursday morning in Naugatuck can blame their downfall on a loud vehicle exhaust pipe. *** A complaint of erratic driving led to a heroin bust in Monroe. When stopped by an officer, the driver reportedly told him he drove erratically because he had to go to the bathroom really, really bad. *** Westport police arrested a driver that was allegedly driving double the posted speed limit. The driver was also double the legal alcohol limit, police said.  *** Greenwich Police say they arrested a motorist who was reportedly following a commercial delivery driver in the wee hours of the morning Feb. 19, thinking the driver was a friend. The motorist was busted for DWI. *** A New Haven man was charged with driving under the influence this week after a golfer found the man lying in the woods bordering the Fairchild Wheeler Golf Course in Fairfield. The man's car was found 50 yards away. *** A Milford man is accused of blocking a former companion's path while she was walking, picking the victim up onto his shoulder and hanging up her cell phone when she attempted to contact 9-1-1 for assistance. *** A man being booked in Norwalk on disorderly conduct charges allegedly became agitated when police wouldn't let him keep his personal effects as he was being processed. He now faces charges of assault on a police officer as well for allegedly becoming physical with an officer several times.

A former Wayne State University student faces five criminal charges, including felony counts of video voyeurism and using a computer to commit a crime, after he allegedly spied on students with  a hidden video camera as they used a restroom  in a campus building. A man using a restroom in State Hall last September spotted the recording device, which was in a backpack positioned between two stalls, and alerted police, the Detroit Free Press reports. The suspect was immediately arrested, and was criminally charged this month. He hadn't been enrolled at the university in more than a year, Wayne State spokesman Matt Lockwood said in a statement. It's unclear  how many people were recorded while using the stalls , Wayne State University Police Chief Dave Spencer told WJBK-TV. Spencer said that in 30 years as a campus police officer, he's never encountered anything like this. Authorities didn't divulge what kind of device was being used, but it wasn't a cell phone camera, according to the WJBK-TV report. Also on Patch: Students interviewed by WJBK-TV said they were unaware of the alleged video voyeurism. Because the suspect was immediately taken into custody, university officials determined there was no imminent threat to students, so they didn't issue a mass email or text message, police said. Lockwood said the university is taking the matter seriously. "We feel for the victims of this invasion of privacy and do not tolerate such criminal behavior," he said. __________ Photo via Flickr

A Revere man was arrested this week in connection with a series of package thefts in Chelmsford. David Gomez, 25, was found with LSD during his arrest and charged with a host of crimes. He is also a suspect in a series of similar package thefts in Wenham. Chelmsford police Chief James Spinney said officers were alerted to Gomez Tuesday by a Berkley Drive resident who reported the suspect stole an envelope out of a mailbox. Officer found Gomez nearby in a white van, Spinney said. "Officers found a cardboard box in the front passenger's seat with multiple items inside," Spinney said in a statement. "Officers seized several Christmas cards, envelopes addressed to sanitation and recycling workers and packages from the vehicle. The cards were addressed to several addresses in both Chelmsford and Wenham." Spinney continued, "Also in the van, a pill bottle was found with what is believed to be a dose of the psychedelic drug LSD inside. In GOMEZ'S pockets, police found $505 in cash that had allegedly been taken from numerous cards and multiple gift cards." Chelmsford police charged Gomez with receiving stolen property over $250, larceny over $250 and drug possession. Wenham police are investigating Gomez and could issue charges. Police said anyone who has been a recent victim of package theft can contact Chelmsford police at  978-256-2521  and Wenham police at  978-468-4000 . Police shared these tips to avoid being a victim of package theft: Photo: David Gomez's mugshot following his arrest in Chelmsford December 19, 2017. (Credit: Chelmsford Police Department)

A Long Valley man is accused of sexually assaulting a teenager multiple times, Warren County Prosecutor Richard T. Burke said. Jose B. Vasquez-Medina, 34, allegedly knew the teen he is accused of assaulting, Burke said. The teen is older than 13 but younger than 16. Vasquez-Medina was arrested on Sept. 13; he was found hiding in a Naughright Road in Long Valley, Burke said. He was charged with aggravated sexual assault, endangering the welfare of a child, and criminal sexual contact.  He had a first appearance in Warren County Court on Sept. 14, but was not released, pending a pre-trial detention motion next week. If found guilty on all charges, he faces up to 50 years in prison.  Image via Shutterstock

Photos courtesy of San Diego County Sheriff''s Department Authorities Tuesday sought the public's help in identifying and finding a man who allegedly pulled a teenager partially into his truck, dragged her along and threw her cell phone at her, because she began recording him when he made sexual comments to her.
